requirement_blocks.title: Core Survey Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Two core survey courses in African American studies; at least one must be pre-20th-century.

course_sources.notes: At least one must be pre-20th-century.

notes: Students are strongly encouraged to complete both survey courses by the end of junior year.

requirement_blocks.title: Junior Seminar
requirement_blocks.description: All majors must complete the junior seminar in research and writing.

requirement_blocks.title: Additional African American Studies Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Six additional African American studies courses.

course_sources.notes: Department may specify level distribution separately.

requirement_blocks.title: Senior Thesis and Colloquium
requirement_blocks.description: All majors must enroll in AAS 498 in the fall and AAS 499 in the spring during senior year.

junior_requirements: AAS 300: Junior Seminar
senior_requirements: AAS 498 (fall)
AAS 499 (spring)

cognates_policy.description: Cognates must be pre-approved by the department.

freshman_sophomore: Begin or complete introductory/survey AAS courses.
junior: Complete both survey courses.
Enroll in AAS 300.
senior: Complete AAS 498 in fall and AAS 499 in spring.

requirement_blocks.title: Prerequisite Anthropology Course
requirement_blocks.description: Students must take one anthropology course (any level) before junior year or have DUS approval.

course_sources.notes: Any level course counts.

requirement_blocks.title: SCA Required Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Three required courses.

requirement_blocks.title: SCA Elective Courses by Distribution
requirement_blocks.description: Six electives across required distributions.

course_sources.notes: Two foundational 200-level courses (one may be cognate).
One 300-level course beyond the core sequence (may be cognate).
One advanced 400-level topical course (may be cognate).
Two free electives (any ANT or cognate).

junior_requirements: Junior paper—anthropological theme, library research-based
senior_requirements: ANT 498 (fall)
ANT 499 (spring)

cognates_policy.description: Up to two cognates allowed at appropriate course levels.

requirement_blocks.title: MedAnth Required Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Four required courses.

course_sources.notes: Foundational medical anthropology course.
Human biology/biological anthropology core.

requirement_blocks.title: MedAnth Elective Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Five electives across designated categories.

course_sources.notes: Two medical anthropology or science/technology courses.
One medicine & society course outside ANT (counts as cognate unless cross-listed).
Two additional ANT electives or one ANT + one cognate.

junior_requirements: Junior paper based on library research
senior_requirements: Thesis on medical anthropology topic

cognates_policy.description: Cognates may include biology, sociology, regional studies, study abroad courses, etc.

requirement_blocks.title: LPE Required Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Three required courses for LPE track.

requirement_blocks.title: LPE Elective Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Six electives spanning law, politics, and economics.

course_sources.notes: Representative list; updated each semester.

junior_requirements: Junior paper (not required to match track)
senior_requirements: Thesis must relate to law, politics, or economics

cognates_policy.description: Appropriate cognates include economics, politics, regional studies, study abroad, or ANT courses outside LPE.

freshman_sophomore: Take prerequisite ANT course
junior: Declare track
Complete core requirements
Junior Independent Work
senior: ANT 498/499 Senior Thesis Sequence

additional_notes: Majors default into SCA unless they declare MedAnth or LPE by spring of junior year.
Track does not appear on transcript but is formally attested by department.

requirement_blocks.title: Prerequisite Introductory Architecture Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Students who wish to major in architecture must complete ARC 203 and ARC 204 during their first or sophomore year; courses do not need to be taken in sequence.

course_sources.notes: ARC 203 is offered only in fall; ARC 204 is offered only in spring.

notes: ARC 206: Geometry and Architectural Representation is highly recommended before junior year but not required.
At least one architectural history course in ARC or ART is recommended before junior year but not required.

requirement_blocks.title: History and Theory Distribution
requirement_blocks.description: Six courses in history and theory of architecture and urbanism, including ARC 308, one architecture history/theory elective, two urbanism electives, and two upper-level ART courses.

course_sources.notes: ARC 308 is taken in the fall of junior year.
One additional history and theory of architecture elective in ARC or a related area.
Two history and theory of urbanism electives.
Two 300- or 400-level courses in Art and Archaeology.

requirement_blocks.title: Building Technology Distribution
requirement_blocks.description: Two courses in building technology, including ARC 311 and one approved technology elective.

course_sources.notes: ARC 311: Building Science and Technology: Building Systems.
One additional building technology elective; offerings vary by year.

requirement_blocks.title: Design/Studio Distribution
requirement_blocks.description: Four design/studio courses including one design seminar and a three-course studio sequence.

course_sources.notes: One design seminar selected from offerings.
ARC 350: Junior Studio I (fall); ARC 351: Junior Studio II (spring); ARC 404: Advanced Design Studio (senior fall).

notes: Studio courses are designed to be taken in sequence: ARC 350 → ARC 351 → ARC 404.
Students must successfully complete each studio in the sequence to move on to the next.

junior_requirements: Junior independent work is satisfied by a ~30-page paper on an architectural topic chosen with a faculty adviser.
Work is initiated in the fall (topic, outline, bibliography) and completed in the spring, with ongoing advising.
A Ph.D. student mentor also provides writing support.
senior_requirements: Year-long senior thesis sequence (ARC 498 in fall, ARC 499 in spring).
Thesis is a detailed research project on a precise architectural theme and may include drawings, models, video, photographs, and computer-generated representations.
Final presentation and oral defense in spring constitute part of the departmental examination.

cognates_policy.description: Program description does not specify use of cognates toward the 12-course requirement; treatment of non-ARC/ART courses should be confirmed with the department.

freshman_sophomore: Complete ARC 203 and ARC 204; they are required prerequisites and do not need to be taken in sequence.
Take ARC 206: Geometry and Architectural Representation (highly recommended but not required).
Take at least one architectural history course in ARC or ART (recommended).
junior: Take ARC 308 in the fall for the history and theory requirement.
Begin studio sequence with ARC 350 (Junior Studio I) in fall and continue with ARC 351 (Junior Studio II) in spring.
Begin junior independent work paper (topic selection, outline, and bibliography in fall; writing in spring).
senior: Complete ARC 404: Advanced Design Studio in the fall.
Enroll in ARC 498 in fall and ARC 499 in spring to complete the senior thesis.
Prepare and deliver final thesis presentation and oral defense in spring.

additional_notes: Students who complete ARC 204 during their first year may take ARC 350 as early as sophomore fall, allowing additional elective studios and flexibility for study abroad during junior year.
Students should consult the academic programs office and director of undergraduate studies to confirm which electives are offered in a given year.

requirement_blocks.title: History of Art Prerequisites
requirement_blocks.description: Any two courses offered by the Department of Art and Archaeology, typically completed in the first or sophomore year.

course_sources.notes: Any two ART courses count toward the prerequisite.

requirement_blocks.title: Core Junior and Advanced Seminars
requirement_blocks.description: Three core seminars within the 10 departmentals: ART 400 (junior seminar) and two additional 400-level seminars (or approved graduate seminars).

course_sources.notes: ART 400 is normally taken in fall of junior year; students abroad may take it in fall of senior year.
Two additional 400-level seminars; approved graduate-level classes may substitute.

requirement_blocks.title: Additional Departmentals and Distribution Requirements
requirement_blocks.description: Seven additional departmentals (for a total of 10 ART courses) with distribution requirements across periods and cultural areas.

course_sources.notes: Seven of the ten total departmentals must be taught by Art and Archaeology departmental faculty.

notes: Students must take courses covering three historical periods and two cultural areas.
ART 100, ART 102, ART 400 and ART 401 count as departmentals but not as distribution courses.
Students are encouraged to explore a range of geographies and media (architecture, painting, sculpture, photography, works on paper, film).
Courses taken for departmental requirements may not be taken pass/D/fail.

junior_requirements: Junior independent work begins in ART 400 and continues into spring with a faculty adviser.
A 30-40 page (7,500-10,000 word) research paper on a topic related to visual and material culture.
Includes two colloquia with the Practice of Art cohort (one in fall, one in spring).
senior_requirements: Year-long senior independent work (60-80 pages / 15,000-20,000 words) under the supervision of a faculty adviser.
Enrollment in ART 498 (fall) and ART 499 (spring) during senior year.
Includes two colloquia with the Practice of Art cohort (one in fall, one in spring).
Senior comprehensive departmental exam: one-hour oral exam on the thesis and departmental coursework with three faculty examiners; exam grade is the average of their grades.

cognates_policy.description: No more than two cognate courses taken in other departments (including VIS) may count toward the 10 departmentals; additional study-abroad courses may be approved as departmentals by the director of undergraduate studies.

requirement_blocks.title: Practice of Art Prerequisites and Portfolio Admission
requirement_blocks.description: Two VIS courses and one ART course, plus portfolio admission to the Program in Visual Arts.

course_sources.notes: Two courses in the Program in Visual Arts.
One course in the Department of Art and Archaeology.

notes: By the first Wednesday following spring break of sophomore year, students submit an application and portfolio to the Lewis Center.
By early April, the Program in Visual Arts admissions committee notifies students accepted into the program.

requirement_blocks.title: Visual Arts Course Requirements
requirement_blocks.description: At least six VIS courses, including studio and seminar requirements; variant structure for film students.

course_sources.notes: Two studio courses in at least two different media (screenwriting counts as a different medium from film production for film students).
Two studio courses at the 300- or 400-level.
VIS 392: Issues in Contemporary Art (junior seminar) is required for all Practice of Art students and film students.
VIS 416 or VIS 417 for most Practice of Art students; VIS 419 (taken spring of junior year) required for film students.

notes: Film students' required VIS structure: two studio courses in two different media, two 300- or 400-level studios, VIS 392, and VIS 419.
Practice of Art students are strongly encouraged to enroll in ART 400; it counts as an ART departmental but not as a distribution course.

requirement_blocks.title: Art and Archaeology Course Requirements
requirement_blocks.description: Four ART courses taught by Art and Archaeology faculty, with distribution across periods and cultural areas.

course_sources.notes: Four ART courses taught by Art and Archaeology faculty.

historical_periods: At least one course covering any other period

notes: For film students: ART courses must include one Group 1 (ancient) or Group 2 (medieval/early modern), one Group 3 (19th century to present), and two from any group.
For two ART courses, film students may substitute film courses cross-listed with ART.
ART 100, ART 102, ART 400 and ART 401 count as departmentals but not as distribution courses.

junior_requirements: Junior independent work begins in the context of the junior seminar (VIS 392) and continues into spring with two advisers (one VIS, one ART).
Students prepare a year-long creative project culminating in an exhibition as part of the spring junior group thesis show; film students create a junior film.
All Practice of Art juniors assemble a writing portfolio (~10 pages / 2,500 words) of multiple short essays reflecting on creative work, broader studies, and art history, with bibliography.
The independent work grade is the average of the VIS and ART advisers' grades.
Includes two colloquia with the History of Art cohort (one in fall, one in spring).
senior_requirements: By the end of the second week of senior fall, students must have three advisers, including at least one ART faculty member.
Year-long senior independent work: a major studio project and a writing portfolio (~20 pages / 5,000 words) with bibliography.
Students enroll in ART 498 (fall) and ART 499 (spring) for senior independent work.
Students receive semiprivate studios and exhibit their work at the Lewis Center at year's end.
Advisers' thesis critique is performed in the presence of the exhibit; the senior independent work grade is the average of the ART and VIS advisers' grades for the critique and written component.

Senior departmental exam includes: (1) a one-hour Crit of the senior thesis exhibition graded by VIS faculty; (2) participation in the same comprehensive exam as History of Art students. The transcript exam grade is the average of the Crit and comprehensive exam grades.

cognates_policy.description: Up to two courses in studio art or art history may be taken at other institutions during summers with prior approval (DUS for History of Art-style courses; VIS director for Practice of Art). Study-abroad courses may count as departmentals with prior approval from both the DUS and VIS director.

junior_requirements: All majors complete structured junior independent work; History of Art students write a 30-40 page research paper, while Practice of Art students complete a junior studio project and writing portfolio.
Junior work in both tracks includes cross-track colloquia linking History of Art and Practice of Art cohorts.
senior_requirements: All majors undertake year-long senior independent work under faculty supervision, with enrollment in ART 498 and ART 499.
History of Art students complete a written thesis; Practice of Art students complete a major studio project and a substantial writing portfolio.
Both tracks participate in senior departmental examinations tailored to their track (thesis oral exam for History of Art; Crit plus comprehensive exam for Practice of Art).

cognates_policy.description: Both tracks allow limited cognates or external courses (including VIS or study abroad) to count as departmentals with prior approval; specific rules differ slightly by track and should be confirmed with the director of undergraduate studies and/or VIS director.

freshman_sophomore: Explore ART and VIS courses; complete prerequisites for the intended track.
History of Art: take at least two ART courses.
Practice of Art: complete two VIS courses and one ART course; prepare application and portfolio for VIS by the first Wednesday after spring break of sophomore year.
junior: History of Art: take ART 400 in fall (or in senior fall if abroad) and begin junior independent work.
Practice of Art: take VIS 392 (junior seminar) and, for film students, VIS 419 in spring.
Begin and carry out junior independent work per track; participate in required colloquia.
Continue progress toward 10 departmentals and required distributions.
senior: Enroll in ART 498 (fall) and ART 499 (spring) and complete senior independent work.
History of Art: complete written thesis and sit for the one-hour senior oral departmental exam.
Practice of Art: complete senior exhibition and writing portfolio, participate in the Crit and comprehensive departmental exam.

additional_notes: The department offers two tracks: History of Art and Practice of Art, each with distinct prerequisite, coursework, and independent work structures.
ART 100, ART 102, ART 400 and ART 401 count as departmentals but not as distribution courses in both tracks.
Students should consult the Undergraduate Handbook and Independent Work Guide for detailed expectations, deadlines, and examples.

requirement_blocks.title: Astrophysical Sciences Prerequisites
requirement_blocks.description: Foundation courses in mathematics, physics, and introductory astrophysics required before entering the major.

course_sources.notes: Equivalent courses (e.g., advanced placement or higher-level courses) may satisfy these requirements.
PHY 103/104 and PHY 105/106 represent alternative introductory physics sequences.
Introductory astrophysics prerequisite.

requirement_blocks.title: Upper-Level Courses in Astrophysics, Physics, and Related Fields
requirement_blocks.description: Students must complete at least eight upper-level (300-400 level) science/math/engineering courses.

course_sources.notes: Students must select at least three AST courses at the 300-400 level.
Students must complete at least three physics courses from this list.
Two additional courses in science, math, computer science, or engineering.

notes: Course selections should be planned with the director of undergraduate studies.
Independent research courses (AST 498/499) do not count toward the eight required upper-level courses.

junior_requirements: Two junior independent research projects (one per semester), each supervised by a faculty adviser.
Projects may involve observational astronomy, data analysis (including SDSS, Hyper Suprime-Cam, Hubble, etc.), theoretical astrophysics, or computational modeling.
Each project culminates in a written research paper submitted at the end of each semester.
Topics may include cosmology, early universe, galaxy formation, quasars, black holes, stars, exoplanets, large-scale structure, plasma astrophysics, or interdisciplinary applications.
senior_requirements: Year-long senior thesis research sequence (AST 498 in fall, AST 499 in spring) conducted under the guidance of a faculty adviser.
Completion of a written senior thesis summarizing research results.
Thesis projects may be observational, theoretical, computational, or interdisciplinary.
The senior thesis is often publishable as part of a scientific paper in an astrophysics journal.
Oral presentation and defense of the thesis after submission.

senior_departmental_exam.description: Consists of the senior thesis work, the oral defense, and a brief oral examination on general topics in astrophysics.
components: Oral summary of thesis research
Formal oral defense evaluated by faculty
General astrophysics oral exam

cognates_policy.description: Additional science, math, CS, or engineering courses may serve as cognates toward the two elective requirements with DUS approval.

freshman_sophomore: Complete math prerequisites (MAT 103-202) and introductory physics sequence (PHY 103/104/105/106/207).
Take AST 204 as the required astrophysics prerequisite.
Begin exploring 300-level physics or astrophysics if prepared.
junior: Begin taking upper-level AST and PHY courses.
Complete two junior independent work projects (fall and spring), each supervised by a faculty adviser.
senior: Complete the AST 498-499 senior thesis sequence.
Complete remaining upper-level AST, PHY, and elective courses.
Prepare oral thesis presentation and senior departmental examination.

additional_notes: There are no tracks in the astrophysics program, but individualized study plans can be developed in consultation with the director of undergraduate studies.
Students interested in graduate study should consider taking additional advanced physics and mathematics courses.
Observational, theoretical, and interdisciplinary research opportunities are widely available and strongly encouraged.

requirement_blocks.title: Chemistry Prerequisites
requirement_blocks.description: Foundational coursework in chemistry, math, physics required before entering the major.

notes: One year of general chemistry required via CHM 201 & 202, CHM 207 & 202, or placement (AP/IB or departmental exam) enabling CHM 202 or CHM 215 or CHM 301.
Placement into CHM 215 or CHM 301 requires departmental placement test or exceptional standardized test performance.

course_sources.notes: Requirement satisfied by any MAT course at MAT 104 level or higher. Prerequisite courses may not be taken P/D/F.
One year of general physics (PHY 101 or 103 or 105; and PHY 102 or 104 or 106), or equivalent via placement.
One year of organic chemistry (CHM 301 & 302 or CHM 301 & 304) taken at Princeton and completed by end of sophomore year.

constraints.grading: Prerequisite courses may not be taken P/D/F.

requirement_blocks.title: Core Departmental Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Four core departmental courses required by University regulations: three upper-level chemistry courses and one experimental course.

notes: Students must complete: one organic (CHM 301/302/304), one physical (CHM 305/306/406), and one inorganic (CHM 411/412).
Three courses must be 300- or 400-level chemistry.

course_sources.notes: Students must complete at least one term of experimental laboratory instruction by end of junior year.

requirement_blocks.title: Cognate Departmental Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Four additional departmental courses in chemistry or closely related sciences/engineering fields.

notes: Cognates may come from molecular biology, engineering, geoscience, materials science, computer science, mathematics, neuroscience, or physics.
Courses must be 300-level or higher (non-introductory) and must contain a strong chemistry component.
Cognates must be individually approved by the director of undergraduate studies.
Chemistry majors often take more than eight departmental courses total.
MAT 201/203 (multivariable calculus) and MAT 202/204 (linear algebra) are strongly encouraged and may count as departmentals.

junior_requirements: Junior Independent Work spans both semesters and consists of a fall research-preparation term and a spring research proposal term.
Fall (Junior Colloquium + Reading Groups):
- Weekly evening Junior Colloquium with research seminars and departmental trainings (e.g., lab safety, RCR).
- Assigned Reading Groups meet across three four-week units; each unit uses current literature to teach scientific reading and writing.
- Students produce three critical analyses of journal articles (one per four-week module).
- Grades determined by DUS based on written work and colloquium attendance.
Spring (Research Proposal Development):
- Students choose a faculty adviser and begin preliminary research toward their senior thesis.
- Students meet regularly with adviser and submit a formal research proposal at the end of the term.
- Grades determined jointly by DUS and adviser.
senior_requirements: Students enroll in CHM 498 (fall) and CHM 499 (spring).
Year-long independent original research project in chemistry, involving experimental and/or theoretical work.
Students submit a written senior thesis conforming to University deadlines.
Thesis evaluated by a committee of faculty—two evaluators from each appropriate area (inorganic, organic, physical, materials science, or biochemistry).
Students present a comprehensive oral thesis presentation during finals period to three faculty members (including adviser).

senior_departmental_exam.description: The senior departmental exam is an oral thesis presentation delivered to a faculty committee.
components: Oral thesis presentation
Evaluation by a three-faculty committee including the thesis adviser

cognates_policy.description: Cognates must be upper-level, non-introductory, and contain a strong chemistry component. Approval from the director of undergraduate studies is required.

freshman_sophomore: Complete general chemistry, general physics, calculus, and begin organic chemistry sequence.
Finish CHM 301/302 or CHM 301/304 by end of sophomore year.
Complete prerequisite courses using letter grading (no P/D/F).
junior: Enroll in advanced core chemistry courses and begin satisfying experimental requirement.
Participate in Junior Colloquium and Reading Groups in fall.
Select faculty adviser and complete preliminary research + formal proposal in spring.
senior: Enroll in CHM 498-499 and carry out year-long senior thesis research.
Prepare and submit written senior thesis.
Present oral thesis defense as departmental examination.

additional_notes: The chemistry program emphasizes flexibility and encourages breadth across physical, organic, inorganic, and interdisciplinary chemical sciences.
Physics and mathematics beyond the minimum prerequisites (multivariable calculus, linear algebra) are strongly recommended.
Departmentals may include approved 500-level graduate courses where appropriate.

requirement_blocks.title: Prerequisite: Classical Culture Course
requirement_blocks.description: One course on classical culture, broadly defined, taken before or at entry to the major.

notes: Any Classics departmental course may count.
HUM 216-217 and HUM 247 also satisfy the prerequisite.
Other courses may be approved by the director of undergraduate studies (DUS).

requirement_blocks.title: Upper-Level Classics Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Eight courses at the 200-level or above (with limited exceptions), including at least two 300-level courses, plus the junior seminar taken separately.

notes: Courses must generally be at the 200 level or above.
At least two courses must be at the 300 level.

requirement_blocks.title: Classics Faculty Taught Requirement
requirement_blocks.description: Five of the eight departmental courses must be taught by Classics faculty.

notes: Courses with CLA, CLG, or LAT as the first listing typically qualify.
Courses taught by affiliated faculty may count with DUS approval.

requirement_blocks.title: Distribution Requirements (Literature, History, Reception/Comparative)
requirement_blocks.description: Three distinct distribution areas: ancient literature, ancient history, and classical reception/comparative approaches.

notes: One course must deal primarily with ancient literature (in the original or in translation).
The CLG/LAT 105-108 sequence may be counted as a single departmental course and used to fulfill this requirement.

course_sources.notes: One course must deal primarily with ancient history, typically fulfilled by CLA 216-219 or an approved alternative.

notes: One course must deal substantially with classical reception or comparative approaches to the ancient world.
This requirement may also be fulfilled by study of another relevant language (e.g., Akkadian, Modern Greek) at any level.

junior_requirements: All majors take CLA 340 (junior seminar) in the fall of junior year, or in fall of senior year if abroad.
In the fall term, each student writes a 12-15 page research paper on a topic chosen with a faculty adviser, with guidance from the junior seminar.
In the spring term, each student writes a more ambitious 20-25 page research paper under close faculty supervision.
senior_requirements: At the end of junior year, students propose a provisional thesis topic and a list of potential faculty advisers to the DUS.
Seniors enroll in CLA 498 (fall) and CLA 499 (spring) to structure thesis progress.
The final thesis is submitted in mid-April of senior year and is completed in addition to the eight required departmental courses.

senior_departmental_exam.description: 30-minute oral comprehensive exam focusing on three topics related to courses completed in the major.
components: Oral exam administered by a committee of two Classics faculty members, supervised by the DUS.
Three topics are chosen based on the student's coursework in the department.

cognates_policy.description: Up to three elective courses may count toward the major if they are cross-listed with Classics or approved by the DUS as relevant to the student's program of study.

requirement_blocks.title: Upper-Level Courses in Ancient History
requirement_blocks.description: Eight courses at the 200 level or above (with limited exceptions), including at least two 300-level courses, plus the junior seminar taken separately.

notes: Ordinarily any CLA, CLG, or LAT course at the 200 level or above will count.
At least two of the eight must be at the 300 level.

requirement_blocks.title: Greek and Roman History Survey Requirements
requirement_blocks.description: One survey in Greek history and one survey in Roman history are required.

course_sources.notes: One survey course on ancient Greek history.
One survey course on ancient Roman history.

requirement_blocks.title: Material Culture Requirement
requirement_blocks.description: At least one course must substantially deal with ancient material culture.

course_sources.notes: May include archaeology and art-history courses in CLA, ART, or related departments with DUS approval.

requirement_blocks.title: Premodern / Non-Industrial History Requirement
requirement_blocks.description: One course on pre-1789 history or non-industrial societies beyond Greece and Rome.

course_sources.notes: Requires DUS approval; must focus on pre-1789 or non-industrial societies outside Greece and Rome.

requirement_blocks.title: Language or Historical Methods Course Option
requirement_blocks.description: One course may be fulfilled by relevant language study or a methods/theory course in history.

course_sources.notes: The CLG/LAT 105-108 sequence may be counted as a single course toward this requirement, or another relevant language at any level may qualify with DUS approval.
An additional course introducing methods, theories, or philosophies of history is strongly encouraged.

junior_requirements: All majors take CLA 340 (junior seminar) in the fall of junior year, or in fall of senior year if abroad.
Fall: 12-15 page research paper under the supervision of a faculty adviser, with structured support from the junior seminar.
Spring: 20-25 page research paper, again with close faculty guidance.
senior_requirements: At the end of junior year, students submit a provisional thesis topic and potential adviser list to the DUS.
Seniors enroll in CLA 498 (fall) and CLA 499 (spring) to support thesis milestones.
Final thesis is due in mid-April of senior year and is completed in addition to the eight required track courses.

senior_departmental_exam.description: 30-minute oral comprehensive exam on three topics related to the student's coursework in the major.
components: Exam administered by two Classics faculty members under DUS supervision during the Senior Comprehensive Examination Period.
Topics chosen to reflect the student's program of study in ancient history.

cognates_policy.description: Additional courses outside CLA/CLG/LAT may count toward the eight required courses if approved by the DUS as relevant to the student's coherent program and independent research goals.

junior_requirements: All Classics majors complete junior independent work anchored by CLA 340 (junior seminar).
Two junior papers are required: a shorter fall paper (12-15 pages) and a longer spring paper (20-25 pages), each under faculty supervision.
senior_requirements: All majors enroll in CLA 498 (fall) and CLA 499 (spring) to complete a senior thesis.
The thesis is submitted in mid-April and is completed in addition to the eight departmental courses required in either program of study.

freshman_sophomore: Complete the prerequisite classical culture course (CLA or approved HUM).
Begin taking 200-level (or above) CLA, CLG, and LAT courses.
Decide between Classical Studies and Ancient History programs in consultation with the DUS.
junior: Take CLA 340 (junior seminar) in the fall (or fall of senior year if abroad).
Complete fall and spring junior papers with faculty advisers.
Work with the DUS to sketch a coherent plan for remaining departmental courses and a provisional thesis topic.
senior: Enroll in CLA 498 and CLA 499 and complete the senior thesis.
Prepare for and sit the 30-minute senior departmental oral examination on three chosen topics.

additional_notes: CLG/LAT 105-108 may be counted as a single departmental course in certain contexts (literature requirement in Program 1, language option in Program 2).
Both programs require eight upper-level departmental courses plus CLA 340 and the CLA 498/499 thesis sequence.
Students are encouraged to work closely with the DUS to ensure a coherent course plan that leads naturally into junior and senior independent work.

requirement_blocks.title: Language Requirement for Admission
requirement_blocks.description: Students must demonstrate proficiency in one non-English language sufficient to take an upper-level literature course in that language by junior year.

notes: Proficiency may be demonstrated by taking an upper-level literature course in the language.
Alternatively, proficiency may be gained through 3 terms of study at Princeton, or 2 terms plus an intensive summer course.
Some students may take a departmental language placement exam.
Proficiency in only one non-English language is required at entry, but majors are expected to study at least one additional non-English language before graduation.

requirement_blocks.title: Recommended Introductory Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Recommended but not required introductory courses for prospective majors.
notes: These courses introduce students to comparative literary study but are not required for admission.

requirement_blocks.title: Comparative Literature Core Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Three courses must be taken within the Department of Comparative Literature, including the junior seminar COM 300.

course_sources.notes: COM 300 must be taken in junior fall unless studying abroad; then it may be taken senior fall.
Two additional courses listed or cross-listed as COM with core faculty.

requirement_blocks.title: Reading-Based Non-English Language Literature Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Four reading-based courses in non-English-language literature departments.

notes: Courses must involve study of texts in the original language and cannot be primarily grammar/vocabulary.
Upper-level (300-400) strongly encouraged, but reading-intensive 200-level courses allowed.
Examples include literature departments in French, Spanish, Italian, German, Russian, Chinese, Japanese, Arabic, Hebrew, Greek, Latin, etc.

requirement_blocks.title: Comparative Literature Pathways (A-E)
requirement_blocks.description: Students choose one of five comparative pathways, each requiring two upper-level courses in the relevant discipline, medium, or area.

required_courses.notes: Two upper-level courses in literature in any language, including English or translated courses.

Path B.title: Literature + Textual Discipline (Humanities or Social Sciences)

required_courses.notes: Two upper-level courses in the chosen textual discipline.

Path C.title: Literature + Medium (Film, Photography, Art, Architecture, Music)

required_courses.notes: Both courses must be in the same artistic medium.
Two upper-level courses in the same regional or ethnic studies area.

notes: Both courses must be in the same creative area.
Admission to this path is provisional; final acceptance depends on approval of a creative thesis proposal and creative arts adviser.
Each path assumes completion of the 4 reading-based non-English literature courses and 3 COM departmental courses.

requirement_blocks.title: Pre-1800 Requirement
requirement_blocks.description: One course must be primarily dedicated to literature, cultures, or historical periods before 1800 C.E.

junior_requirements: Two junior papers:
- First JP (~3,000 words): close reading of a non-English literary text.
- Second JP (~8,000 words): broader comparative project, often a precursor to the senior thesis.
senior_requirements: Year-long senior thesis under COM 498 (fall) and COM 499 (spring).
Thesis is 15,000-20,000 words and should be comparative in nature.
Creative theses must include a substantial critical essay.

senior_departmental_exam.description: Thirty-minute oral exam testing intellectual and analytical skills from coursework and independent work.
components: Conversation with thesis adviser (first reader) and one additional COM faculty examiner.

cognates_policy.description: Cognates may be counted if relevant to the student's comparative focus and approved by the department.

freshman_sophomore: Begin studying at least one non-English language.
Take optional introductory courses such as COM 205-206, HUM 216-219, or TRA 200.
junior: Take COM 300 in the fall (or senior fall if abroad).
Write two junior papers.
Declare pathway (A-E).
Continue advanced language/literature coursework.
senior: Enroll in COM 498-499 and complete senior thesis.
Prepare for senior departmental examination.

additional_notes: Upper-level theory courses (COM 301, COM 303) are recommended for students interested in literary theory.
Language competency beyond the entrance requirement is expected for graduation.

requirement_blocks.title: Prerequisite Courses for A.B. Computer Science
requirement_blocks.description: Math, computing, and systems foundations required before entering or progressing in the major.

course_sources.notes: Any one of MAT 202, 204, or 217 satisfies the math prerequisite. EGR 154 may be used as an alternative.
EGR 154 is an approved alternative to the MAT 202/204/217 requirement.
Students should plan to take COS 126 in the first year.
ECE 115 may substitute for COS 126.
COS 217 and COS 226 must be completed before junior year; one or both are prerequisites for most upper-level COS courses.

notes: Students with a general interest in science or engineering are encouraged to take COS 126 in the first year to preserve the option to major in computer science.

requirement_blocks.title: Foundation Course
requirement_blocks.description: All majors must complete a foundational course in reasoning and computation.

course_sources.notes: COS 240: Reasoning and Computation must be completed before the end of junior year.

requirement_blocks.title: Core: Computer Systems
requirement_blocks.description: One course in computer systems is required.

notes: Primary options: COS 316 (Principles of Computer System Design) or COS 375 (Computer Architecture and Organization).
Alternatives: COS 417 (Operating Systems), COS 418 (Distributed Systems), COS 461 (Computer Networks).

requirement_blocks.title: Core: Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning
requirement_blocks.description: One course in AI/ML is required.

notes: Primary option: COS 324 (Introduction to Machine Learning).
Alternatives: COS 429 (Computer Vision), COS 435 (Introduction to Reinforcement Learning), COS 484 (Natural Language Processing).

requirement_blocks.title: Core: Theoretical Computer Science
requirement_blocks.description: One course in theoretical computer science is required.

notes: Options include COS 330 (Great Ideas in Theoretical Computer Science),
COS 423 (Theory of Algorithms), COS 433 (Cryptography),
COS 445 (Networks, Economics, and Computing), COS 487 (Theory of Computation).

requirement_blocks.title: Core: Breadth Requirement
requirement_blocks.description: One course providing breadth beyond core systems/theory/AI-ML or emphasizing real-world applications.

notes: Breadth courses include: COS 326 (Functional Programming), COS 333 (Advanced Programming Techniques), COS 343 (Algorithms for Computational Biology),
COS 426 (Computer Graphics), COS 432 (Information Security), COS 436 (Human-Computer Interaction), COS 448 (Innovating across Technology, Business, and Markets).

requirement_blocks.title: Upper-Level Electives
requirement_blocks.description: Three additional upper-level courses that deepen or broaden work in computer science or approved related disciplines.

course_sources.notes: Three COS courses at the 300- or 400-level. Note: 500-level graduate COS courses do not count as electives for this requirement.
Up to two electives may be chosen from a department-approved list of courses in other departments (see the Computer Science department website for the current list).

notes: All eight departmental courses (foundation + four core + three electives) must be taken for a grade (not P/D/F).
Students should consult a COS academic adviser when planning their core and elective selections.

junior_requirements: All A.B. majors complete junior independent work (IW) under supervision of a COS faculty member.
Fall of junior year:
- Enroll in a Junior Research Workshop (JRW).
- Simultaneously enroll in a 300-level 'methods' course offered that term.
- Use the JRW + methods course to develop a comprehensive proposal for a spring IW project.
Spring of junior year:
- Complete the proposed IW project OR begin a separate research project.
- IW may be done via one-on-one advising with a faculty member or via an Independent Work Seminar around a common theme.
senior_requirements: All A.B. majors complete a full-year senior thesis through COS 498A-499B.
The senior thesis is a substantial independent project in computer science or its applications and may extend junior IW work or address a new topic.
Thesis projects may involve research, systems building, applications, entrepreneurship, or policy/ethics in computing.

cognates_policy.description: Up to two approved courses from other departments may count as departmentals (electives) from an official list maintained by the Computer Science department.

freshman_sophomore: Take COS 126 (or ECE 115) in the first year.
Complete math prerequisite (MAT 202/204/217 or EGR 154).
Complete COS 217 and COS 226 by the end of sophomore year.
junior: Complete COS 240 if not already done.
Start taking core 300-level COS courses across systems, AI/ML, theory, and breadth.
Fall: Enroll in JRW and a 300-level methods course; write an IW proposal.
Spring: Complete junior independent work project.
senior: Enroll in COS 498A (fall) and COS 499B (spring) for the senior thesis.
Finish remaining core and elective departmentals.
Consider interdisciplinary or application-focused electives aligned with thesis or career goals.

additional_notes: The major has no formal tracks, but students can shape informal concentrations via their core and elective choices (e.g., systems, AI/ML, theory, HCI, security, etc.).
Interdisciplinary combinations with fields such as mathematics, economics, molecular biology, neuroscience, linguistics, music, art, and engineering are common and encouraged.
Students should consult the Computer Science department website for up-to-date lists of approved outside electives, methods courses, and independent work opportunities.

requirement_blocks.title: Prerequisites
requirement_blocks.description: One year of language study in an East Asian language and one 200-level EAS course.

course_sources.notes: One full year of study in Chinese, Japanese, or Korean.
One 200-level EAS-prefixed course.

requirement_blocks.title: Junior Seminar
requirement_blocks.description: All majors must take EAS 300, normally in the fall of junior year.

course_sources.notes: Introductory methods survey for the major.

requirement_blocks.title: Transnational East Asia Requirement
requirement_blocks.description: At least two approved transnational courses are required.

course_sources.notes: Students choose any two.

allows_double_counting_with.notes: These courses may count toward both transnational and premodern, but only count as one EAS-prefixed departmental.

requirement_blocks.title: Premodern East Asia Requirement
requirement_blocks.description: At least one course on premodern East Asia.

course_sources.notes: May include HIS 207 or HUM 233, which can simultaneously fulfill the transnational requirement.

requirement_blocks.title: EAS Departmentals Requirement
requirement_blocks.description: A minimum of six of the eight departmental courses must be EAS-prefixed.

requirement_blocks.title: Two Additional Departmental Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Two additional courses may be EAS courses, approved cognates, upper-level language courses, or courses in a second East Asian language.

course_sources.notes: May include cross-listed EAS courses.
Must be approved by the DUS.
Language courses at or above the 300 level after the third-year proficiency requirement is fulfilled.
Any courses in a second East Asian language.

language_proficiency.required_level: Third-year proficiency in one East Asian language
language_proficiency.description: Majors must demonstrate proficiency through the third-year level in Chinese, Japanese, or Korean before graduation.

junior_requirements: Fall: Enroll in EAS 300 (junior seminar) and complete a junior independent work paper.
Spring: Complete a second junior independent work paper under faculty supervision.
By end of junior year: Draft a provisional senior thesis proposal.
senior_requirements: Seniors enroll in EAS 498 (fall) and EAS 499 (spring).
Senior thesis must be an original contribution to East Asian Studies using source materials in the student's primary language.
Scholarship funding for research abroad is available via SAFE and related programs.

senior_departmental_exam.description: A faculty committee oral defense focused on the senior thesis and broader fields of East Asian Studies.
components: Conversation begins in the student's primary research language (Chinese, Japanese, or Korean).
Discussion of thesis development, research process, and scholarly context.

cognates_policy.description: Cognate courses may count toward additional departmentals if approved by the director of undergraduate studies.

freshman_sophomore: Complete one year of an East Asian language.
Take at least one 200-level EAS course.
Begin progressing toward third-year language proficiency.
junior: Enroll in EAS 300 and complete two junior independent works.
Take transnational and premodern courses as needed.
senior: Enroll in EAS 498 and 499.
Complete senior thesis and oral defense.

additional_notes: A single course may not be used to fulfill two requirements except HIS 207 and HUM 233, which may count for both transnational and premodern content—but still count as only one EAS-prefixed departmental.
Language beyond third-year proficiency and second East Asian language study are encouraged but not required.

requirement_blocks.title: Prerequisites
requirement_blocks.description: Introductory biology, chemistry, calculus, physics, and a statistics course, normally completed by end of sophomore year.

course_sources.notes: Two terms of introductory biology: EEB 211 and either MOL/EEB 214 or MOL/EEB 215.
Mastery of calculus to MAT 103 or above; AP may substitute.
Two terms of introductory chemistry via CHM 202 + (CHM 201 or CHM 207), AP or placement accepted.
One term of introductory physics.
Statistics should be completed before junior year; must be completed by end of fall senior year.

constraints.grading: Prerequisite courses may not be taken P/D/F.

requirement_blocks.title: Core Upper-Level EEB Requirements
requirement_blocks.description: EEB majors must take EEB 309 and EEB 321.
notes: Students are encouraged to take EEB 309 and EEB 321 in fall of junior year or earlier.

requirement_blocks.title: Area Distribution Requirements
requirement_blocks.description: Students must complete one course in two of the four designated areas.

course_sources.notes: *Courses with asterisk are part of semester abroad program.

requirement_blocks.title: Additional Upper-Level Departmental Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Students must complete eight upper-level departmental courses total; after core & area courses, remaining departmentals may be chosen from EEB or up to two approved outside courses.

course_sources.notes: Up to two non-EEB courses may count. For MOL: first semester organic chemistry and MOL 345 count; second semester organic chemistry does not.
With DUS preapproval, one policy/society course relevant to science may count.

constraints.grading: No departmental course may be taken P/D/F; minimum grade C-.
constraints.study_abroad_policy: Study abroad courses may count only if preapproved; letter grades do not transfer.

junior_requirements: Fall: Attend research presentations and identify potential advisers.
Fall: Participate in tutorial and write first junior paper.
Spring: Conduct independent research and write second junior paper (research project, literature review, or research proposal).
senior_requirements: Select a thesis adviser in fall of junior year.
Enroll in EEB 498 (fall) and EEB 499 (spring).
Carry out independent research (lab, field, theoretical, data-mining, or library study).
Write a senior thesis presented at end of spring term.

senior_departmental_exam.description: One-hour oral exam consisting of a defense of the thesis and general questions in the biological sciences.
components: Defense of thesis research
Broader biological science questions

cognates_policy.description: Up to two non-EEB departmentals may count toward the eight departmental courses with DUS approval.

freshman_sophomore: Complete biology, chemistry, physics, calculus, and statistics prerequisites.
Begin exploring EEB 200-level or 300-level courses.
junior: Take EEB 309 and EEB 321.
Complete two area distribution courses.
Write junior papers in fall and spring.
Arrange senior thesis adviser by end of year.
senior: Enroll in EEB 498 and 499.
Carry out senior thesis research.
Complete oral departmental examination in May.

additional_notes: Integrated Science Sequence students must consult the DUS about upper-level EEB placement.
Premedical students should consider EEB 314 and consult Health Professions Advising early.

requirement_blocks.title: Prerequisites
requirement_blocks.description: Introductory economics, statistics, and calculus prerequisites to be completed by end of sophomore year with a grade of C or better.

course_sources.notes: Students must complete ECO 100 and ECO 101 with a letter grade of C or better.

notes: The statistics prerequisite may be satisfied by ECO 202, ORF 245, or the combination of POL 345 + POL 346.
POL 345 alone does NOT satisfy the statistics requirement.
PSY 251, SPI 200, and SOC 301 are NOT accepted for the statistics prerequisite.
The basic math prerequisite is MAT 175 or an approved substitute.
ECO 201, EGR 156, or MAT 201 may substitute for MAT 175.

Students intending to take ECO 312 or upper-level finance courses (ECO 462, ECO 465, ECO 466) or pursue graduate study are strongly encouraged to take MAT 201 and MAT 202 instead of only one semester of MAT 175 or EGR 156.

constraints.stats_summer_policy: Statistics prerequisite may not be satisfied with a summer course taken after matriculation at Princeton except in highly unusual circumstances approved by the Executive Director of Undergraduate Studies.
constraints.timeline: All prerequisites should be completed by the end of sophomore year.

requirement_blocks.title: Departmental Course Requirements
requirement_blocks.description: Economics majors must complete eight graded departmental courses and maintain a minimum departmental average of C.

course_sources.notes: Departmentals include three core courses and five additional departmentals (ECO 300-, 400-, or 500-level courses or approved cognates).

constraints.grading: All departmental courses must be taken for a letter grade (no P/D/F).

notes: The calculation of the departmental average and the treatment of failed courses are described on the department website.

requirement_blocks.title: Core Microeconomics
requirement_blocks.description: All majors must complete one intermediate microeconomics course.

notes: ECO 300: Intermediate Microeconomics (requires MAT 175).
ECO 310: Microeconomic Theory: A Mathematical Approach (requires MAT 201).

constraints.timeline: Must be completed during or before junior year.

requirement_blocks.title: Core Macroeconomics
requirement_blocks.description: All majors must complete one intermediate macroeconomics course.

notes: ECO 301: Intermediate Macroeconomics (requires MAT 175).
ECO 311: Macroeconomic Theory: A Mathematical Approach (requires MAT 201).

constraints.timeline: Must be completed during or before junior year.

requirement_blocks.title: Core Econometrics
requirement_blocks.description: All majors must complete one econometrics course.

notes: ECO 302: Econometrics (requires MAT 175).
ECO 312: Econometrics: A Mathematical Approach (requires MAT 201 and MAT 202).

constraints.timeline: Must be completed during or before junior year.

requirement_blocks.title: Other Departmental Courses
requirement_blocks.description: In addition to the three core courses, majors must complete five additional departmental courses.

course_sources.notes: Any 300-, 400-, or 500-level ECO course may count as a departmental.
Up to two approved cognates from other departments may count as departmentals; see cognates_policy for automatic and approved options.

constraints.grading: All departmentals must be taken for a letter grade (no P/D/F).

notes: Students planning an empirical senior thesis are strongly encouraged to take ECO 313.
Students planning a theoretical senior thesis are strongly encouraged to take ECO 317 and/or ECO 418.

requirement_blocks.title: PPE Politics Prerequisites
requirement_blocks.description: To enter the PPE program, students must complete two politics courses at any level by the end of sophomore year, in addition to all economics prerequisites.

course_sources.notes: Any two graded POL courses satisfy this prerequisite.

constraints.timeline: Completed by end of sophomore year along with ECO and math prerequisites.

requirement_blocks.title: PPE Politics Departmentals
requirement_blocks.description: PPE students must complete three upper-level politics courses during junior and senior years.

course_sources.notes: At least three 300-level (or higher) politics courses are required.
With advance approval, one of the three may be a politics-related course from a department other than POL or ECO.

constraints.grading: All PPE politics departmentals must be taken for a letter grade.

track_specific_notes: PPE students have the same junior and senior independent work requirements as other economics majors.
PPE students are required to write a junior paper with sufficient political economy content, as judged by the adviser.
PPE students are encouraged, but not required, to write a senior thesis related to political economy.

additional_notes: PPE participants must satisfy prerequisites for both the Economics and Politics departments by the end of sophomore year.
Because of additional PPE requirements, students often count one or two politics departmentals as economics cognates, subject to standard ECO cognate approval rules.
Some politics courses (e.g., POL 347, POL 349, POL 352, POL 385) are automatically approved as economics cognates and do not require a separate application.
In rare cases and only with advance approval, an economics course may count toward the PPE politics requirement; this must be arranged with the political economy faculty adviser.
PPE is formally recognized by a departmental attestation for students who complete all requirements.

junior_requirements: All juniors complete a year-long independent research project in economics.
Fall: submit a research prospectus (proposal) in December.
Spring: submit a final junior paper in April that critically analyzes an economic problem using economic principles.
senior_requirements: All seniors complete a full-year senior thesis through ECO 498 (fall) and ECO 499 (spring).
The thesis is a more extensive and in-depth research project than the junior paper, with broader analysis and interpretation.
Details on adviser assignment, milestones, and deadlines are provided in the department's junior independent work and senior thesis guides.

senior_departmental_exam.description: Written comprehensive exam covering intermediate microeconomics, macroeconomics, and econometrics.
components: Written exam on core microeconomics (ECO 300/310 level content).
Written exam on core macroeconomics (ECO 301/311 level content).
Written exam on core econometrics (ECO 302/312 level content).

cognates_policy.description: Economics majors may count a maximum of two courses from other departments as cognates. Cognates must have substantial theoretical or empirical economic content. Courses with ECO cross-listing (ECO 3XX, 4XX, 5XX as first or second listing) count as regular departmentals, not cognates.
approval_process_notes: For non-automatic cognates, students must submit a cognate approval form with a course syllabus to the undergraduate program manager.
Approval must be obtained before the semester's grading option deadline.
Cognates are approved by the Executive Director of Undergraduate Studies; approval is never granted retroactively.

freshman_sophomore: Complete ECO 100, ECO 101, ECO 202 (or approved statistics substitute), and MAT 175 (or approved math substitute) by the end of sophomore year.
For students targeting ECO 312 or advanced finance/graduate study, complete MAT 201 and MAT 202 for a letter grade.
Students considering study abroad should meet with the Director of Undergraduate Studies early (ideally first year).
junior: Complete core courses in microeconomics, macroeconomics, and econometrics (ECO 300/310, ECO 301/311, ECO 302/312).
Begin and complete junior independent work (prospectus in fall, junior paper in spring).
PPE students: complete at least some 300-level politics departmentals and ensure junior paper has political economy content.
senior: Enroll in ECO 498 (fall) and ECO 499 (spring) and complete the senior thesis.
Finish remaining economics departmentals and any approved cognates.
Sit for the written senior comprehensive exam in core micro, macro, and econometrics.

additional_notes: A meeting for sophomores interested in joining the department is typically held in the spring.
Underclass students are welcome to meet with the Director of Undergraduate Studies to discuss planning and requirements.
Students interested in graduate work in economics or finance are strongly encouraged to pursue the more mathematical versions of the core and additional coursework in mathematics.

requirement_blocks.title: Prerequisites
requirement_blocks.description: There are no formal prerequisites, but students are advised to take at least one English course during their first or second year.

requirement_blocks.title: Junior Seminar
requirement_blocks.description: All majors must take ENG 300, the junior seminar, in the fall of junior year. This course introduces research methods and prepares students for junior independent work.

requirement_blocks.title: Literary and Cultural History (LCH)
requirement_blocks.description: Majors must complete one designated Literary and Cultural History (LCH) course.

course_sources.notes: LCH courses address tradition and transmission across long historical periods.

requirement_blocks.title: Pre-1700 Literature
requirement_blocks.description: At least one course in literature and culture before 1700.

requirement_blocks.title: 1700-1900 Literature
requirement_blocks.description: At least one course in literature and culture from 1700-1900.

requirement_blocks.title: Post-1900 Literature
requirement_blocks.description: At least one course in literature and culture from 1900 to the present.

requirement_blocks.title: Difference and Diversity (D&D)
requirement_blocks.description: Majors must take one D&D course that examines literature in relation to race, ethnicity, gender, sexuality, class, or other forms of difference.

requirement_blocks.title: Theory and Criticism (T&C)
requirement_blocks.description: Majors must take one course in Theory and Criticism.

requirement_blocks.title: Additional Departmental Courses
requirement_blocks.description: In addition to the junior seminar, senior thesis courses, and distribution requirements, majors complete three additional English departmental courses.

course_sources.notes: Counts any English-prefixed or English cross-listed course unless taken P/D/F.

constraints.grading: No P/D/F allowed for English courses, including cross-listed courses.

requirement_blocks.title: Senior Thesis Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Two senior thesis courses taken in the senior year.

notes: Students accepted to the Creative Writing minor may count two CWR courses as English departmentals.
Students may substitute a Creative Writing thesis for the English thesis with approval.
Students accepted to the Theater minor may count two THR courses as English departmentals.

junior_requirements: Take ENG 300 (Junior Seminar) in the fall.
Write one junior paper of 20-30 pages, begun in the seminar and completed in the spring.
Students receive advising on spring course selection through the seminar.
senior_requirements: Write a senior thesis of 60-75 pages on a topic developed with a faculty adviser.
Enroll in ENG 498 in fall and ENG 499 in spring.
Each course includes assignments and deadlines to scaffold the thesis process.

senior_departmental_exam.description: All English majors take a senior departmental examination. Details provided on the English department website.

cognates_policy.description: Students pursuing interdisciplinary minors may count up to one course outside English toward the major if they can demonstrate strong intellectual connection and receive DUS approval.
approval_process_notes: Cognates must be pre-approved by the Director of Undergraduate Studies.
Courses taken abroad: up to two may count as departmental courses.

requirement_blocks.title: Language Sequence Prerequisite
requirement_blocks.description: Admission requires completion of the French or Italian language sequence, or equivalent qualification.

course_sources.notes: Successful completion of FRE 107 or FRE 108 (or equivalent).
Successful completion of ITA 107 or ITA 108 (or equivalent).

constraints.equivalents_notes: Equivalent qualification may include placement, prior study, or other certification approved by the department.

notes: Students are encouraged (but not required) to complete at least one advanced language course (FRE 207, FRE 207F, FRE 208; ITA 207I, ITA 208) prior to or shortly after admission.
It is further recommended to complete at least one additional 200-level course before enrolling in a 300-level course.

requirement_blocks.title: Advanced Language Course Requirement
requirement_blocks.description: All majors are expected to include at least one advanced language course in their major subject(s).
notes: Any two of the listed 200-level and above courses (FRE 207, 208, 211, 215, 217, 221, 222, 224, 225; ITA 207, 208, 209, 220, 224, 225) can count toward the eight upper-division courses required for the major, subject to track rules.

requirement_blocks.title: Departmental Course Pool (200-level and Above)
requirement_blocks.description: Courses that may count as departmentals for the major, subject to per-track limits and DUS approval.

notes: Upper-division courses taught in English may count only if all written work is completed in French or Italian.
Per-track rules limit how many 200-level courses can count toward the five primary language courses.
Majors planning to do minors (e.g., African Studies, AAS, ECS, LAS, GSS) must also satisfy the prerequisites of those programs.

requirement_blocks.title: Junior Seminar
requirement_blocks.description: All majors complete the junior seminar in French (FRE 398).
notes: FRE 398 introduces majors to advanced methods and topics in French/Francophone studies.

requirement_blocks.title: Senior Thesis Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Credit-bearing senior thesis sequence for French and Italian majors.
notes: Starting with the Class of 2026, FIT 498 and FIT 499 are credit-bearing thesis courses.
FIT 498 is graded on components such as meetings with adviser, abstract, bibliography, outline, short literature review, and an oral presentation; FIT 499 grade is the thesis grade.

tracks.track_name: Track 1: Major in One Language, Literature, and Culture

requirement_blocks.title: Primary Language Courses
requirement_blocks.description: At least five upper-division courses in the language and subject of the major (French or Italian).

course_sources.notes: Primary language is declared as French or Italian at time of concentration.

restricted_200_level_pairs: FRE 207 & FRE 208 may not both be counted together toward the five primary-language courses.
ITA 207 & ITA 208 may not both be counted together toward the five primary-language courses.

requirement_blocks.title: Additional Upper-Division Courses and Cognates
requirement_blocks.description: Three additional upper-division courses to complete the eight required; may include cognates with approval.

course_sources.notes: Cognates may come from other sections of the department or from humanities and social sciences with strong relevance.

notes: Students major in either French or Italian.
Eight upper-division courses total; at least five in the primary language and culture.

tracks.track_name: Track 2: Major in Two Languages, Literatures, and Cultures

requirement_blocks.title: Primary Language Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Five upper-division courses in the primary language (French or Italian); one may be a cognate.

restricted_200_level_pairs: FRE 207 & FRE 208 may not both be counted together toward the five primary-language courses.
ITA 207 & ITA 208 may not both be counted together toward the five primary-language courses.

requirement_blocks.title: Secondary Language Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Three upper-division courses in the second language and culture.

course_sources.notes: Secondary language is the other language (French or Italian) not chosen as primary.

notes: Designed for students combining French and Italian (or French/Italian with another language in a structured way, as approved by the DUS).

tracks.track_name: Track 3: Major in French or Italian and Another Field

requirement_blocks.title: Primary Language Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Five upper-division courses in French or Italian language and literature; one may be a cognate.

restricted_200_level_pairs: FRE 207 & FRE 208 may not both be counted together toward the five primary-language courses.
ITA 207 & ITA 208 may not both be counted together toward the five primary-language courses.

requirement_blocks.title: Related Field Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Three upper-division courses in a related field (e.g., history, politics, art and archaeology).

course_sources.notes: Typically 300-level or higher courses in a humanities or social science discipline; chosen in consultation with the DUS.

notes: Students combine French or Italian with another disciplinary field; course plan should be approved with the DUS before enrollment.

tracks.track_name: Track 4: Major in French or Italian and the Creative Arts

requirement_blocks.title: Primary Language Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Five upper-division courses in French or Italian language and literature.

restricted_200_level_pairs: FRE 207 & FRE 208 may not both be counted together toward the five primary-language courses.
ITA 207 & ITA 208 may not both be counted together toward the five primary-language courses.

requirement_blocks.title: Creative Arts Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Three upper-division courses in a creative art (e.g., theater, music, dance, painting, film, translation, creative writing).

course_sources.notes: All three courses should be in the same creative medium; requires DUS approval.

notes: Students may, with approval, substitute an original creative or performance project for the senior thesis, but not for the junior paper.
A creative thesis must be accompanied by a substantial critical essay (6,000-10,000 words) situating the creative work in its historical and cultural context.
The creative component must have a clear French/Francophone or Italian cultural component approved in advance.

junior_requirements: Students are paired with an adviser by the beginning of junior year after discussing interests with the DUS (no later than spring of sophomore year).
One junior paper (8,000-10,000 words) due at the end of spring term.
If written in English, a three-page summary in the relevant language (French or Italian) is required.
If written in the relevant language, a three-page summary in English is required.
Formatting should follow MLA or Chicago style and conform to University guidance on writing.
senior_requirements: Seniors write a thesis (15,000-20,000 words) on an approved topic in French/Francophone or Italian studies, potentially including culture, literature, language, or related themes.
Students enroll in FIT 498 (fall) and FIT 499 (spring). FIT 498 includes graded milestones (adviser meetings, abstract, bibliography, outline, literature review, and an oral presentation).
The thesis may be written in English with a three-page summary in the relevant language, or in the relevant language with a three-page summary in English.
For Tracks 2-4, joint supervision may be arranged to reflect work across languages or fields/arts.

senior_departmental_exam.description: A two-part senior departmental examination (written + oral) testing the student's command of the language and the broader field of study.

components.name: Written Exam (3 hours)
details: Sight translation from French or Italian into English of a short prose text.
An essay in the language of specialization on one of several culture/literature topics drawn from reading lists and course offerings.
For Track 2 (French and Italian), the sight translation text is in the dominant language.

components.name: Oral Presentation (30 minutes)
details: A 10-15 minute oral presentation in the major language (French or Italian), followed by discussion.
May draw on the senior thesis and/or broader coursework in the major.
Examining committee includes at least two permanent faculty from the relevant section(s).

cognates_policy.description: Cognates must be approved by the DUS and should have clear relevance to the student's program of study. Track-specific limits apply (e.g., Track 1 allows up to three cognates among the eight upper-division courses; Tracks 2-3 generally allow one cognate in the primary language block; Track 4 focuses more on primary language + creative arts).
additional_notes: Upper-level courses taught in English only count if all written work is completed in French or Italian.
Students pursuing minors (e.g., African or Latin American Studies, AAS, ECS, GSS) should coordinate cognate choices with both the DUS and the minor program.

freshman_sophomore: Complete the language sequence in French or Italian (FRE 107/108 or ITA 107/108, or equivalent).
Begin advanced language courses (e.g., FRE 207/208 or ITA 207/208) and at least one additional 200-level course before moving to 300-level work.
Discuss possible interest in minors or track choices (especially for Tracks 2-4) with the DUS.
junior: Be formally assigned a junior adviser at the start of junior year.
Complete FRE 398 (junior seminar) and plan the junior paper.
Write and submit the junior paper (8,000-10,000 words) by end of spring term.
Clarify and formalize which track (1-4) you are following.
senior: Enroll in FIT 498 in the fall and FIT 499 in the spring.
Develop, draft, and complete the 15,000-20,000 word senior thesis (or approved creative + critical thesis in Track 4).
Prepare for and take the written and oral components of the senior departmental examination.

additional_notes: Track choice (1-4) determines how the eight upper-division courses are distributed across French/Italian and related languages/fields/arts.
Advanced language study beyond the minimum is strongly encouraged, especially for students considering graduate work or long-term engagement with French/Francophone or Italian studies.

requirement_blocks.title: Prerequisites to Declare
requirement_blocks.description: Three prerequisite courses required to declare the major. All must be completed with a grade of C- or better; no pass/D/fail allowed.

course_sources.notes: One geosciences course required.
One mathematics prerequisite.
One core science course; see GEO website for approved Chemistry/Physics/Biology/Statistics courses.

constraints.grading_requirement: C- or better; no P/D/F permitted.

requirement_blocks.title: Core Science Requirements
requirement_blocks.description: Five core science requirements in chemistry, physics, biology, and statistics, completed by end of junior year.

course_sources.notes: Full list of approved courses maintained on GEO website. Must include chemistry, physics, biology, and statistics.

requirement_blocks.title: Core GEO Requirements
requirement_blocks.description: Two core GEO courses required. The fall course satisfies the junior independent work requirement.

course_sources.notes: "Research Methods in Geosciences" counts as fall JP. See GEO for specific core course listings.

requirement_blocks.title: GEO Electives
requirement_blocks.description: Five upper-level (300+) GEO or GEO cross-listed departmental electives.

course_sources.notes: Electives must be 300-level or above; includes cross-listed GEO courses.

constraints.notes: Courses not primarily listed in GEO require DUS approval. Electives may include approved GEO-adjacent courses.

junior_requirements: Two terms of junior projects (JP).
Fall: enroll in 'Research Methods in Geosciences' covering experimental design, data collection, statistics, Python, visualization, and proposal writing. This course counts as the fall JP.
Spring: conduct independent research under a Princeton GEO faculty adviser or approved external adviser (with GEO faculty co-adviser for study abroad).
Students must meet regularly with advisers and maintain ongoing research engagement.
senior_requirements: Enroll in GEO 498 (fall) and GEO 499 (spring).
Complete an original, year-long senior thesis with regular adviser meetings and sustained research commitment.
Attend a minimum of three departmental seminars each term (≥3 in fall, ≥3 in spring).
Present thesis work at the senior oral comprehensive exam.
Fieldwork (often international) may be included; GEO provides tools and support for laboratory, computational, or field-based research.

senior_departmental_exam.description: A comprehensive oral examination based on the senior thesis and related geoscience topics.
components: Oral presentation of the senior thesis, followed by faculty questions.
Exam graded by at least two non-advising GEO faculty members.
Grade recorded separately from GEO 498/499.

cognates_policy.description: Some upper-level science courses may count toward GEO electives if approved by the DUS. Only Princeton courses count, except in the case of pre-approved study abroad.
additional_notes: Cognates count toward electives but not core GEO requirements.
No pass/D/fail allowed for any departmental courses.
Minimum grade for departmental credit is C-.

freshman_sophomore: Complete prerequisite GEO, math, and one core science requirement.
Begin fulfilling core science sequences (chemistry, physics, biology, statistics).
Meet with GEO DUS or undergraduate program manager early to design a course plan.
Attend GEO open houses offered fall and spring.
junior: Finish all prerequisites and core science requirements by end of junior year.
Fall: take Research Methods in Geosciences (fall JP).
Spring: complete spring junior independent research project.
Select GEO electives (300+) and begin focusing on desired subfields such as geology, climate science, paleontology, biogeochemistry, or geophysics.
senior: Enroll in GEO 498 and GEO 499.
Conduct senior thesis research across the full academic year.
Attend ≥3 departmental seminars per term.
Complete and present the senior thesis at the oral comprehensive exam.

additional_notes: GEO research infrastructure includes mass spectrometry, spectroscopy, DNA probes, electron microscopy, supercomputing, and global fieldwork opportunities.
Students should see the GEO website and GEO Undergraduate Handbook for detailed lists of approved core science courses, GEO electives, and independent work expectations.

requirement_blocks.title: Language Prerequisite and Placement
requirement_blocks.description: A satisfactory working knowledge of German demonstrated by coursework, standardized testing, or departmental proficiency exam.

course_sources.notes: Completion of GER 107 (or the 101-107 sequence) satisfies the departmental prerequisite.

Alternatively, a qualifying standardized test score prior to matriculation or successful completion of the departmental proficiency exam may satisfy the prerequisite and allow placement in 200- or 300-level courses, as well as eligibility for Princeton in Vienna, the Summer Work Program, and the Berlin Consortium for German Studies.

notes: Students considering the major are encouraged to consult the DUS early to design a coherent plan of study.

requirement_blocks.title: Junior Seminar
requirement_blocks.description: Required junior seminar GER 300 counts as one of the nine departmental courses.

course_sources.notes: GER 300 is normally taken in the first term of junior year and serves as an intensive research and writing workshop.

requirement_blocks.title: German Literature Departmentals and Cognates
requirement_blocks.description: Eight additional departmental courses beyond GER 300, focusing on major periods and forms of German literature.

course_sources.notes: At least five courses must be in the German department; at least three of these should be 300-level or above.
Up to three cognate courses in related humanities such as philosophy or religion.

language_requirements.notes: At least three departmentals must be taught in German; one of these three may be a course taught in English with an approved German-language component.

requirement_blocks.title: Philosophy and Intellectual History Departmentals and Cognates
requirement_blocks.description: Eight additional departmental courses emphasizing philosophy, political/cultural theory, and intellectual movements in German-speaking contexts.

course_sources.notes: At least five courses must be in the German department; at least three of these should be 300-level or above.
Up to three relevant cognate courses in history, European cultural studies, and/or philosophy.

requirement_blocks.title: Media and Aesthetics Departmentals and Cognates
requirement_blocks.description: Eight additional departmental courses focusing on art, film, dance, music, sound technology, and/or media theory.

course_sources.notes: At least five courses must be in the German department; at least three of these should be 300-level or above.
Up to three relevant cognates in ART, VIS, film, music, philosophy, dance, European cultural studies, architecture, etc.

requirement_blocks.title: Linguistics Core Requirements
