requirement_blocks.description: Core courses in linguistics and the history/structure of German.

course_sources.notes: LIN 201: Introduction to Language and Linguistics or a comparable linguistics course.
GER 505: History of the German Language.
Either GER 506 or GER 316: Second Language Acquisition and Pedagogy.

requirement_blocks.title: Literature, Culture, and Linguistics Cognates
requirement_blocks.description: Additional courses completing the eight courses beyond GER 300.

course_sources.notes: At least three courses in German literature and culture.
Two cognate courses pertaining to linguistics (e.g., further LIN courses or linguistics-related offerings in other departments).

requirement_blocks.title: German and Second Literature Departmentals
requirement_blocks.description: Eight additional courses split between upper-level German and a second literature.

course_sources.notes: Five upper-level German department courses, at least three at the 300 level.
Three upper-level courses in a second literature. Language preparation for the second literature must be completed by the end of junior year.

tracks.track_name: Joint Program in German Culture and Politics

requirement_blocks.title: Joint Program in German Culture and Politics
requirement_blocks.description: Eight additional courses combining German intellectual history with German/European politics and political theory.

course_sources.notes: Four courses in the German department, at least two at the 300 level. Recommended: GER 207, 208, 211, 306, 307, 309, 324.
Four cognate courses in German/European politics or political theory in the Department of Politics, at least two at the 300 level. Recommended: POL 210, 230, 240, 385.

language_requirements.notes: At least two departmentals must be taught in German.

notes: The senior thesis may focus on any political topic with a substantive German-related component.
Graduates receive a departmental attestation letter certifying completion of a program in German cultural studies with a major in politics.

junior_requirements: Independent reading, the junior seminar GER 300, a junior essay, and senior thesis together constitute the student's total independent work.
GER 300, taken in the first term of junior year, functions as an intensive workshop in research and writing methods and incubates the junior paper.
Junior paper: approximately 8,000 words on a topic in German philosophy, art, media, linguistics, literature, or politics; may be written in German or English.
Students should discuss senior thesis ideas with the DUS in late April of junior year.
senior_requirements: Year-long senior thesis on an approved topic, written in German or English.
By the end of week 4 of fall term, students submit a tentative thesis outline to their adviser.
Further progress reports as required by the department.
Five weeks before the departmental exam, submit a signed PDF thesis to the adviser and DUS.
After the exam and approval, submit an electronic thesis (PDF) for the department archive and library per University instructions.

senior_departmental_exam.description: An approximately hour-long oral examination based on the thesis and the student's overall course of study.
components: 5-10 minute presentation (in English or German) summarizing the thesis argument and its contribution to the field.
Question-and-answer discussion with faculty examiners about the thesis and broader program of study.
At least one-quarter of the exam is conducted in German.

cognates_policy.description: Depending on the track, up to three cognate courses in related disciplines (philosophy, history, ECS, POL, art history, linguistics, etc.) may count toward the eight courses beyond GER 300. All cognates must have clear relevance to the student's German-focused plan of study and be approved by the DUS.
additional_notes: Some tracks (e.g., Joint Program in German Culture and Politics, German Linguistics) have more specific cognate structures and department constraints encoded within their track-level requirement blocks.

freshman_sophomore: Complete GER 107 or demonstrate equivalent proficiency via standardized test or departmental proficiency exam.
Begin taking 200-level GER courses and explore potential track interests.
Consult the DUS early about study abroad options such as Princeton in Vienna, the Summer Work Program, or the Berlin Consortium for German Studies.
junior: Enroll in GER 300 (Junior Seminar) in fall.
Complete the junior paper (~8,000 words) in connection with GER 300 and subsequent advising.
Refine track choice and ensure language and cognate requirements for the chosen track are on track.
Discuss preliminary senior thesis topics with the DUS in late spring.
senior: Develop and complete the senior thesis under supervision of a faculty adviser.
Meet thesis outline and progress deadlines set by the department.
Submit thesis PDF five weeks before the exam, then complete the oral departmental examination.
Submit final electronic copy of the thesis for departmental and library archives.

additional_notes: Students who place directly into 200- or 300-level German via testing or proficiency exam may be immediately eligible for departmental study and approved summer/abroad programs.
Track selection should be made in consultation with the DUS to ensure coherent integration of German courses, cognates, and independent work.
The junior paper and senior thesis may be written in German or English; students are encouraged to align their language choice with their long-term goals and proficiency.

requirement_blocks.title: Foundational Preparation for Mathematics
requirement_blocks.description: Prospective majors must have a strong background in linear algebra, single- and multivariable analysis, and experience with rigorous proof-based mathematics. Students may begin in different course sequences depending on preparation.

course_sources.title: Path A: Advanced Start
course_sources.description: For students with strong prior calculus.

course_sources.title: Path B: Proof-Intensive Start
course_sources.description: For students with rigorous proof experience.

course_sources.title: Path C: Introductory Theoretical Preparation
recommended_sequence: MAT 210 or MAT 214 → MAT 215 → MAT 217 → MAT 300

course_sources.title: Path D: Non-proof Calculus Start
course_sources.description: For undecided majors or those initially planning another quantitative major; proofs not emphasized.
course_sources.notes: Students should meet early with junior advisers to plan a move into the 215-217-300 proof sequence.

notes: Most majors begin 300-level work by the second semester of sophomore year.
Students should consult the junior adviser or associate DUS early to plan a suitable trajectory.

requirement_blocks.title: Core Course Requirements
requirement_blocks.description: All Mathematics majors must complete four core upper-level mathematical subjects.

replacement_option.description: One discrete math course may replace the geometry/topology requirement.

notes: Students are encouraged to complete some core requirements by the end of sophomore year.

requirement_blocks.title: Upper-Level Departmental Requirements
requirement_blocks.description: Beyond the four core courses, students must complete four additional 300-level (or higher) courses.

notes: Up to three upper-level courses may be cognates from other departments, if approved.
No more than two of the eight total departmental courses may be reading courses.
Cognates require permission from a junior adviser, senior adviser, or the director of undergraduate studies.
Programs of study may be arranged for fields such as applied mathematics, physics, biology, finance, or computer science.

requirement_blocks.title: Senior Thesis Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Mathematics majors must complete a full-year senior thesis via MAT 498 and MAT 499.

junior_requirements: Junior independent work typically consists of participating in a junior seminar in both fall and spring.
Students may alternatively replace one junior seminar with supervised reading in a special topic and a written paper.
Junior advisers help students plan an academic pathway and select suitable independent work topics.
senior_requirements: Senior independent work consists of a year-long thesis completed through MAT 498 (fall) and MAT 499 (spring).
Many students collaborate with faculty in other departments (e.g., physics, computer science, finance, molecular biology) on interdisciplinary mathematical problems.

senior_departmental_exam.description: An oral examination conducted in May.
components: Defense of the senior thesis.
Discussion of broader mathematical context and the subfield connected to the thesis.

cognates_policy.description: Up to three upper-level courses outside mathematics may be counted toward the major if approved.
rules: Cognates must form part of a coherent mathematical or interdisciplinary plan of study.
Approval may be granted by the junior adviser, senior adviser, or DUS.
No more than two of the eight departmental courses may be reading courses.

freshman_sophomore: Choose an appropriate calculus/proofs pathway (103-104-201-202, 203-204, 210/214, or 215/216).
Begin transitioning into the 215-217-300 sequence as soon as feasible.
Complete at least some core requirements (analysis, algebra, or topology) by the end of sophomore year.
Consult early with the associate DUS or junior adviser to plan long-term mathematical development.
junior: Enroll in junior seminars in fall and spring.
Engage in independent work supervised by a faculty member.
Select courses that prepare for the senior thesis and deepen subfield interests.
senior: Enroll in MAT 498 and MAT 499.
Work closely with a thesis adviser on an advanced mathematical research project.
Prepare for the oral senior departmental examination.

additional_notes: The departmental average of the eight mathematical courses, along with grades and evaluations of independent work, is used for awarding honors.
Students interested in applied mathematics, theoretical mathematics, or interdisciplinary applications should build coherent clusters of analytically related courses.
Students should consult Course Offerings to determine availability of key upper-level electives in a given year.

requirement_blocks.title: Prerequisites for Entering the Department
requirement_blocks.description: Students must complete foundational biology and chemistry prior to declaring the MOL major. All prerequisites must be taken for a letter grade (no P/D/F), except that students may appeal to uncover one P grade when declaring the major.

course_sources.title: Biology Requirement
notes: Grade of C or better required.

courses: Departmental placement test → CHM 215 or CHM 202

course_sources.title: Integrated Science Sequence (ISC)
course_sources.description: Students entering via the Integrated Science Curriculum fulfill prerequisite requirements through the equivalent ISC course series.

notes: Organic chemistry (CHM 301 & CHM 304, or CHM 337) must be completed before junior year.

requirement_blocks.title: General Molecular Biology Requirements
requirement_blocks.description: Students must complete organic chemistry, quantitative coursework, and physics prior to graduation. Organic chemistry must be completed before junior year.

categories.name: Organic Chemistry
categories.requirements: Must be completed before junior year.

categories.name: Quantitative Requirement
categories.requirements: Two courses: one statistics + one CS or math.
notes: AP credit cannot satisfy quantitative requirements.
Statistics requirement cannot be substituted by outside courses; second course may be substituted with prior approval.

categories.name: Physics Requirement
notes: PHY 108 is a one-semester biologically oriented alternative.
Premeds needing two semesters may combine PHY 101 or 103 with PHY 108.
No AP or transfer credit allowed for physics.

requirement_blocks.title: Departmental Core Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Four core MOL courses must be completed by the end of junior year. MOL 320 and MOL 350 are considered equivalent; only one may be taken.

notes: Core courses count toward the eight required departmentals.
No substitutions except in rare cases such as approved study abroad replacing MOL 350.
Deferral to senior year requires written permission from the DUS.

requirement_blocks.title: Additional Departmentals
requirement_blocks.description: Students must complete at least eight total departmentals including four cores. The remaining courses must be upper-level MOL or approved related courses.

course_sources.title: Approved Non-MOL Departmentals
course_sources.notes: Other approved upper-level science courses appear on the department website.

notes: Only Princeton courses count toward departmentals.
No pass/D/fail allowed for prerequisites, requirements, or departmentals.
Students may appeal to uncover one P grade only at the point of declaring the major.

junior_requirements: Fall: participation in postdoc-led tutorials analyzing primary scientific literature; two critical analysis papers required.
Spring: independent work with the faculty adviser who will supervise the senior thesis, concluding with a junior paper written as a grant proposal.
senior_requirements: Full-year senior thesis research (MOL 498-499).
Project may be laboratory- or non-laboratory-based and must involve sustained research.
A fall progress report is due on Dean's Date.
A written thesis must be submitted in the spring.

senior_departmental_exam.description: A 30-minute oral defense of the senior thesis before two faculty readers (excluding the adviser).
components: Presentation of thesis background and major findings
Defense of methodology and conclusions
Discussion of future research directions

cognates_policy.description: The MOL department does not allow cognates. All departmentals must be Princeton MOL, MOL-cross-listed, or preapproved upper-level courses from the department list.
rules: CHM 301, CHM 304, and CHM 337 count automatically as departmentals.
Study abroad substitutions require advance DUS approval.

freshman_sophomore: Complete MOL 214 as early as possible.
Finish general chemistry and begin organic chemistry.
Complete physics requirement (preferably PHY 108).
Begin quantitative requirements (statistics + CS/math).
junior: Complete all four core MOL courses.
Fall tutorials → critical papers; spring → junior grant proposal.
If taking MOL 320, do so early (sophomore spring) if planning to study abroad.
senior: Enroll in MOL 498 and MOL 499 for thesis research.
Submit progress report in fall.
Complete written thesis and oral exam in spring.

additional_notes: Organic chemistry must be completed before junior year.
MOL 320 is intended for early research-exploring sophomores; MOL 350 is the standard junior fall core.
Students planning study abroad should consult the DUS early.
Premed students can fulfill physics via PHY 101/103 combined with PHY 108.

requirement_blocks.title: Prerequisite Distribution Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Students must complete one course in Materials and Making (M&M) and one course in Culture and Criticism (C&C) before entering the major.

notes: See the course 'Other Information' section to determine whether a course counts as M&M.
See the course 'Other Information' section to determine whether a course counts as C&C.
Students are encouraged to consult the DUS early (ideally in first year) to plan potential paths through the curriculum.

requirement_blocks.title: Culture and Criticism (C&C) Departmentals
requirement_blocks.description: Two additional courses in Culture and Criticism beyond the C&C prerequisite.

notes: These are taken in addition to the one C&C prerequisite course.
Cognate courses cannot be used to satisfy C&C distribution.

requirement_blocks.title: Materials and Making (M&M) Departmentals
requirement_blocks.description: Two additional M&M courses beyond the M&M prerequisite, for a total of three M&M courses. At least one of the three must include a significant musicianship/ear-training component.

notes: Total requirement: three M&M courses (one prerequisite + two additional).

ear_training_requirement.description: At least one of the three total M&M courses must include a significant musicianship/ear-training component.
ear_training_requirement.approval: An alternative course may be approved by the director of undergraduate studies.

requirement_blocks.title: Additional Music Electives
requirement_blocks.description: Three additional electives in music and related areas, at least two of which must be at the 300 level or higher.

course_sources.notes: Includes MUS courses and MUS-prefix cross-lists.
Performance courses (MPP) may count as departmentals under class-year and track-specific rules (see notes).

notes: If a student is approved to enroll in a graduate seminar that is graded P/D/F, it may still count toward the course requirement with DUS approval.
Class of 2026: majors who are also in the music performance minor may count one performance course (e.g., MPP 213, 214, 216, 219, 251, 252, MUS 340) as a departmental.
Class of 2027 and beyond: majors in the music performance track may count up to two performance courses (such as MPP 213, 214, 216, 219, 251, 252, etc.) as departmentals, subject to track rules.

requirement_blocks.title: Junior Seminar
requirement_blocks.description: A required junior seminar that introduces methods and issues in the study of music and scaffolds the junior project.

course_sources.notes: Normally taken in fall of junior year; students abroad may complete it in fall of senior year.

requirement_blocks.title: Senior Thesis Course Sequence
requirement_blocks.description: Credit-bearing year-long sequence that supports research, composition, or performance-based senior thesis projects.

course_sources.notes: Beginning with the Class of 2026, MUS 498 (fall) and MUS 499 (spring) track thesis progress through assignments and deadlines.

requirement_blocks.title: Performance Courses Counting as Departmentals
requirement_blocks.description: Performance-track majors may count MPP performance courses as departmentals, subject to class year and program rules.

notes: Class of 2026 music majors who are also in the music performance minor may count one performance course (e.g., MPP 213, 214, 216, 219, 251, 252, MUS 340) as a departmental.
Class of 2027 and beyond, for students in the music performance track: up to two performance courses (e.g., MPP 213, 214, 216, 219, 251, 252, etc.) may be counted as departmentals, with DUS approval.
MPP 298/299 (lessons for credit) may reflect lesson work on the transcript but do not themselves count toward the separate MPP-course participation requirements of the track.

requirement_blocks.title: Ensemble Participation, Studio Lessons, and Senior Recital
requirement_blocks.description: Additional performance obligations for students in the music performance track.
notes: Ensemble participation in an approved faculty-led department ensemble is required in all four semesters of the junior and senior years, in the instrument/voice/tradition for which the student was admitted (or an approved equivalent).
Studio lessons with a department studio instructor or program director are required for all semesters the student is on campus; details vary by performance area.
Students may choose to enroll in lessons for credit (MPP 298/299), but this course does not itself count toward the MPP-course requirement described above.
A senior recital or program-specific performance in senior year is required and forms a core part of the senior thesis for performance-track students.
Admission to the music performance track is by competitive audition in spring of sophomore year; students must demonstrate a high level of proficiency in an instrument, voice, or conducting.

cognates_policy.description: Performance-track students follow the same cognate rules as the general music major; up to two relevant courses in other departments may count as cognates with DUS approval.

junior_requirements: Enrollment in MUS 300 (Junior Seminar) in the fall, which introduces methods in music research, scholarship, composition, and performance and includes a formal proposal for the junior project.
Junior independent work (JP) is due in the spring of junior year and is developed with a faculty adviser, beginning from the proposal formulated in MUS 300.

Typical JP formats include: (a) research project (approx. 30-40 pages / 7,500-10,000 words); (b) composition (approx. 6-10 minutes) with a short contextual paper; (c) performance project for performance-track students, combining a significant performance, a supplemental written/lecture component, and a jury before a faculty panel.
Hybrid JPs combining research, composition, and/or performance are allowed; scope and format are worked out with the adviser.
senior_requirements: Year-long senior thesis project, tracked through MUS 498 (fall) and MUS 499 (spring), under the supervision of a faculty adviser.
Research theses typically consist of a substantial written study of approximately 60-80 pages (30,000-40,000 words).
Composition theses typically consist of 12-20 minutes of original music plus a contextual essay.

Performance theses include a senior recital (or approved performance project) plus a substantial supplementary component (e.g., lecture, written program, research paper, short composition, critical edition/arrangement, or public humanities project) related to the performance practice.
Hybrid senior theses combining research, composition, performance, and/or public humanities components are allowed with adviser approval.
Each thesis is read by a second faculty reader; the thesis grade is the average of the adviser's and second reader's grades.

senior_departmental_exam.description: A scheduled senior thesis presentation followed by a question period with faculty.
components: A senior thesis presentation (up to 30 minutes) summarizing the project's motivation, methodology, and results, and/or presenting samples from the work.
A 10-15 minute Q&A period immediately following the presentation with the thesis adviser and other faculty in attendance.

cognates_policy.description: Up to two courses from other departments may count as cognates if they contribute significantly to the student's music major and/or independent work.
rules: Cognates must be approved by the DUS no later than the University's add/drop deadline; they cannot be approved retroactively.
Cognate courses do not satisfy music distribution requirements (M&M or C&C), but they do count toward departmental standing and honors.
Cross-listed courses with MUS as a listing (e.g., STC/MUS 204, STC/MUS 209) are automatically departmentals, not cognates.

Examples of relevant cognates include CS/engineering courses for electronic music pathways, anthropology for sound studies, psychology/neuroscience for music cognition, or history for historical musicology.

freshman_sophomore: Complete one M&M and one C&C course to satisfy prerequisites.
Begin exploring additional M&M and C&C courses and performance opportunities.
For students interested in the music performance track, prepare for the audition held in the spring of sophomore year.
junior: Take MUS 300 (Junior Seminar) in the fall (or in senior fall if abroad).
Begin junior project planning in MUS 300 and complete JP in spring under a faculty adviser.
Continue satisfying C&C, M&M, and elective requirements, ensuring at least two electives at the 300 level or higher.
Performance track: enroll in required ensembles and studio lessons each term on campus.
senior: Enroll in MUS 498 (fall) and MUS 499 (spring) and carry out the year-long senior thesis.
Complete all remaining distribution and elective requirements.
Give the required senior thesis presentation (and senior recital if in the performance track).

additional_notes: Majors design their program of study in close consultation with the director of undergraduate studies and are encouraged to meet with the DUS in their first year.
Students are encouraged to pursue both their strengths and areas outside their comfort zone when selecting courses.
Admission to the Music Performance Track is competitive and by audition in the spring of sophomore year; the program supports preparation for professional performance or graduate study.

requirement_blocks.title: Prerequisites
requirement_blocks.description: A student who has completed at least one course in the department is eligible to major in Near Eastern Studies.

notes: This may be any NES course, including a language class or disciplinary seminar.

requirement_blocks.title: Departmental Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Students must complete eight departmental courses, including NES 300 and seven additional departmentals that meet distribution requirements.

notes: NES 300 (Seminar in Research Methods) must be taken in junior year unless studying abroad; in that case, NES 300 is taken senior year.
Language courses beyond the second year count as departmentals.
Courses in a second Near Eastern language at any level may count as departmentals.
Cognates must be approved by the DUS.
All departmental courses must also satisfy distribution requirements listed below.

requirement_blocks.title: Historical Period Distribution
requirement_blocks.description: Students must take at least one premodern NES course and at least one modern NES course.
notes: A single course may satisfy historical + regional + disciplinary areas simultaneously.
However, a course cannot satisfy both the premodern and modern requirement.

requirement_blocks.title: Regional Distribution
requirement_blocks.description: Students must take two regionally specific courses, each representing a different region from the six-subregion list.

areas_required: The Levant, Iraq and the Arabian Peninsula

requirement_blocks.title: Disciplinary Distribution
requirement_blocks.description: Students must take at least one course in two separate disciplinary areas.

language_requirements.description: Students must complete four semesters (through the 107 level) of Arabic, Hebrew, Persian, or Turkish.
notes: Students are encouraged to begin language study early.
Advanced language study is encouraged, especially for thesis work.
Language proficiency may be completed via Princeton courses, intensive summer study, or study abroad.

junior_requirements: Students write one junior paper over the course of the junior year.
A JP proposal (outline + annotated bibliography) is submitted in fall.
Completed junior paper is submitted in the spring.
Students must enroll in NES 300 in junior year unless abroad, in which case NES 300 is taken senior year.
senior_requirements: Students complete a year-long senior thesis under a faculty adviser.
Senior thesis is taken as NES 498 (fall) and NES 499 (spring).
Thesis topics must be approved by the adviser.
Students are encouraged to consult NES Senior Thesis Guidelines.

senior_departmental_exam.description: A one-hour oral comprehensive exam administered by the thesis adviser and second reader.
components: Defense of the thesis.
Discussion of the student's overall experience in the department based on the comprehensive statement.

cognates_policy.description: Up to three cognates may count toward the eight departmental courses with DUS approval.

additional_notes: A single course may satisfy multiple distribution categories across historical/region/discipline domains.
A course may not satisfy more than one category *within* a domain.
Students seeking non-standard plans must apply for a waiver from the undergraduate committee.

requirement_blocks.title: Prerequisites
requirement_blocks.description: To enter the neuroscience major, students must complete at least one foundational NEU course (NEU 201 or NEU 202) and MAT 103 or equivalent.

notes: Students must complete both NEU 201 and NEU 202 prior to graduation.
Neither NEU 201 nor NEU 202 must be taken before the other.
Standardized test placement may fulfill MAT 103.

requirement_blocks.title: Core Program Requirements
requirement_blocks.description: Students must complete the following required neuroscience and supporting science courses.

notes: Placement into or out of PHY 101 is determined by the Department of Physics.

requirement_blocks.title: Cell Biology Requirement
requirement_blocks.description: Students must complete one 200-level or higher course in cell biology.

notes: Standardized test outcomes cannot fulfill this requirement.

requirement_blocks.title: Statistics Requirement
requirement_blocks.description: Students must complete one statistics course.

notes: Other statistics courses may count with DUS approval.

requirement_blocks.title: Neuroscience Electives
requirement_blocks.description: Students must take six NEU electives with representation across four subject areas.
notes: Elective lists are maintained on the NEU website.
Class of 2027 may follow older rules (behavior cognate + 5 NEU electives covering 3 areas).
Class of 2028 and beyond must follow the updated structure above.

requirement_blocks.title: Cognate Courses
requirement_blocks.description: Students may take two cognate courses that count as electives.

junior_requirements: Fall term: Students read primary literature and prepare analytical papers under adviser supervision.
Spring term: Students write a research proposal with their future senior thesis adviser.
senior_requirements: Students complete a year-long senior thesis under a faculty adviser.
Students enroll in NEU 498 (fall) and NEU 499 (spring).
A written progress report is required at the end of fall semester.

senior_departmental_exam.description: An oral defense of the senior thesis presented to two faculty readers.
components: Discussion of thesis background
Defense of research findings
Future directions for research
senior_departmental_exam.grading: Average of the two faculty readers' grades

additional_notes: Both NEU 201 and NEU 202 must be completed prior to graduation, though only one is required to declare.
Class-year-specific elective rules apply (2027 may use old rules; 2028+ must use new subject-area requirements).

requirement_blocks.title: Prerequisites
requirement_blocks.description: Any course offered by the Philosophy Department may serve as a prerequisite for entering the major.

notes: Students without this prerequisite by the end of sophomore year must request admission from the Director of Undergraduate Studies (DUS).

requirement_blocks.title: Departmental Distribution Requirements
requirement_blocks.description: Majors must complete at least eight philosophy courses. Six of these must be distributed as two courses in each of three of the four philosophy areas. The remaining two courses are unrestricted.

tracks.description: Available to senior majors writing their thesis in political philosophy. Provides an alternate way to meet distribution requirements.

requirements.title: Politics Theory Courses
notes: Courses must be those listed by the Department of Politics as political theory.

requirements.title: One Additional Philosophy Area
notes: Any one of the remaining three philosophy distribution areas.

tracks.description: For senior majors writing theses in philosophy of science. Provides alternative distribution rules.

requirements.title: Upper-Level Science Courses
notes: Courses must be 300-level or higher in one relevant science: mathematics, computer science, physics, biology, psychology, economics, etc.

tracks.description: For philosophy majors pursuing the linguistics minor. Uses the Philosophy of Science track structure with linguistics treated as the science.

notes: Courses listed under the Program in Linguistics (core, other, or related) are considered courses in the science of linguistics.

junior_requirements: Fall: participation in a junior seminar with weekly or biweekly meetings, culminating in a 5,000-word research paper.
Spring: writing a junior paper (≈5,000 words) under supervision of an individual faculty adviser.
senior_requirements: Senior thesis through PHI 498 (fall) and PHI 499 (spring), 10,000-15,000 words.
Thesis proposal due before fall recess.
Annotated bibliography and extended outline due Dean's Date of fall.
Interim draft (≈5,000 words) due just after winter recess.

senior_departmental_exam.description: A 90-minute oral exam covering the general area of philosophy to which the thesis belongs.
components: Discussion of thesis argument
Broader philosophical context
Reading list topics agreed upon by adviser and exam coordinator

additional_notes: Tracks only modify distribution requirements; all students complete the same independent work.
Students may substitute courses only under approved track structures.

requirement_blocks.title: Prerequisites
requirement_blocks.description: Five prerequisite courses must be completed by end of sophomore year. These may not be taken pass/D/fail.
notes: Students beginning physics in sophomore year should consult the DUS early.
PHY 109/110 (spring/summer sequence) is fully equivalent to PHY 104.

requirement_blocks.title: Departmental Requirements
requirement_blocks.description: Students must complete eight upper-level departmental courses plus the senior thesis sequence PHY 498-499.

course_groups.title: Upper-Level Physics Courses
notes: One 300-level or higher physics course (not including cross-lists)
One 300-level or higher physics course (cross-lists allowed)
One additional 300-level or higher course in physics or mathematics (including cross-lists)

course_groups.title: Elective Course Requirement
requirements: One elective at the 300-level or above
May be physics (including cross-lists) OR a related science/engineering/math course with DUS approval
notes: 400-level physics courses strongly recommended.
Graduate courses may be taken with instructor + DUS permission.

junior_requirements: Two junior papers on research topics of current interest.
Each paper written in close consultation with a faculty adviser working in the relevant research area.
Junior independent work may alternatively be satisfied with a short experimental project.
senior_requirements: Full-year senior thesis completed through PHY 498 (fall) and PHY 499 (spring).
Thesis topic may be experimental, theoretical, or interdisciplinary (e.g., geophysics, history of science).
Students with advisers outside the Physics Department must designate a Physics co-adviser.

senior_departmental_exam.description: An oral examination conducted by a departmental committee at the end of senior year.
components: Defense of the senior thesis
Questions on related areas of physics

additional_notes: Thesis courses PHY 498 and PHY 499 do not count among the eight departmental courses.

requirement_blocks.title: Prerequisites
requirement_blocks.description: Normally, students must successfully complete at least two graded Politics (POL) courses by the end of sophomore year. These are considered the prerequisites and also count as departmentals.

course_groups.title: Politics Course Prerequisites
requirements: At least two POL courses taken on a graded basis before the end of sophomore year.
Prerequisites may not be taken pass/D/fail.
Prerequisite courses count as departmentals and may be used to satisfy field distribution requirements.
It is strongly recommended that one or both prerequisites be at the 200 level.

course_groups.title: Analytical Prerequisite Constraint
requirements: If exactly two prerequisites are taken, they may not both be analytical courses (e.g., POL 345 and POL 347).
If two analytical courses are used as prerequisites, a third non-analytical POL course is required by the end of sophomore year.

course_groups.title: Special and Study Abroad Cases
requirements: On a case-by-case basis, the DUS may count a course taught by regular Politics faculty in another department (not cross-listed with POL) as a departmental, and possibly as a prerequisite and/or toward field distribution.
Prospective majors studying abroad sophomore year may receive credit for up to two approved politics-related study abroad courses as prerequisites.
Students cannot declare the Politics major without having taken at least one POL course at Princeton.

requirement_blocks.title: Departmental Course Requirements
requirement_blocks.description: Politics majors must complete at least 11 departmental courses, including prerequisites, POL 300, an analytical requirement course, and additional upper-level work.

course_groups.title: Departmental Course Count
requirements: Minimum of 11 departmental courses in Politics (including the two prerequisites).
POL 300 counts as one of the 11 departmentals.
A course satisfying the analytical requirement is included within the 11 departmentals.
Up to two of the 11 departmentals may be approved cognates (see Cognates block).
All departmentals must be taken for a grade (no pass/D/fail).
Students must attain an overall average of C or higher across all departmentals.

course_groups.title: Field Distribution Requirement (3-2-1 Rule)
course_groups.description: Students must take courses in at least three of the four Politics subfields, designating a primary, secondary, and tertiary field.
requirements: Primary field: at least 3 courses.
Secondary field: at least 2 courses.
Tertiary field: at least 1 course.
One of the three primary-field courses is normally at the 200 level (recommended but not required).
Prerequisite POL courses may count toward field distribution.
Courses used to fulfill the analytical requirement may NOT be used to satisfy any field distribution requirement.
Methods in Political Science courses may not be chosen as the primary field.

fields.name: Methods in Political Science (cannot be primary field)

requirement_blocks.title: Analytical Requirement
requirement_blocks.description: All Politics majors must complete one course emphasizing formal or quantitative methods for political analysis, normally no later than the first semester of junior year.

requirement_blocks.title: POL 300 Requirement
requirement_blocks.description: All Politics majors must take POL 300: Conducting Independent Research in Political Science in the fall semester of junior year.

course_groups.title: POL 300 Structure
requirements: POL 300 counts as a departmental course.
Students choose a lecture track upon registration:
L01 (Technical track): assumes preparation such as POL 345, ECO 202, ORF 245 or equivalent.
L02 (Conceptual track): no prerequisites; emphasizes qualitative, historical, and theory-oriented approaches.
Both tracks cover similar topics; L01 is more statistically intensive.

requirement_blocks.title: Cognates
requirement_blocks.description: Up to two (or, in special programs, three) courses in other departments may count as departmentals if they have substantial political content.

course_groups.title: Standard Cognate Rules
requirements: Up to 2 cognates may count as departmentals for most students.
Cognates must be outside the Politics department and have at least 50% politics content.
Cognates must be taken in junior or senior year, except:
- Courses outside POL that satisfy the analytical requirement, or
- Upper-level Economics courses used for the Political Economy track.
Cognates may NOT be used to satisfy field distribution requirements.
Cognates must be pre-approved by the cognate approval adviser, with syllabus, by the stated deadline.
Once approved as a cognate, a course cannot be de-approved.
Approved cognates must be taken for a grade and are included in the honors calculation.

course_groups.title: Special Interdisciplinary Programs (3 Cognates)
requirements: Students may design a special program combining Politics with another discipline or region (e.g., Politics and Religion, Politics and Psychology, Public Policy and Bioethics, Politics of the Near East).
Approved special programs may allow up to 3 cognates to count as departmentals.
Students must submit a written proposal (normally by end of junior year) demonstrating how the 3 cognates form a coherent interdisciplinary program.
Special program approval is required from the department.

tracks.track_name: Track in American Ideas and Institutions
tracks.description: Optional departmental track for Politics majors focusing on the ideas, institutions, and development of American politics. Students follow additional, track-specific course guidance while still meeting all standard Politics major requirements.
notes: Only Politics majors may pursue this track.
Courses may double-count for both major and track requirements.
Track completion results in a departmental attestation (noted on Class Day, not on the transcript).
See departmental track webpage and the track adviser for up-to-date approved courses and requirements.

tracks.description: Optional track focusing on the intersection of politics and economics, including political institutions, markets, and economic policy.
notes: Only Politics majors may pursue this track.
Some upper-level Economics courses may be required and may count as cognates or departmentals per approval.
Track courses must be taken for a grade and factor into honors.
See the Political Economy track webpage for specific course lists and thesis expectations.

tracks.track_name: Track in Quantitative and Analytical Political Science
tracks.description: Optional track emphasizing formal theory and quantitative methods in the study of political behavior, institutions, and international relations.
notes: Only Politics majors may pursue this track.
Students typically take additional methods and statistics courses beyond the analytical requirement.
Courses may double-count for the track and the Politics major.
See the Quantitative and Analytical Political Science track webpage for detailed requirements.

tracks.description: Optional track for students focusing on race, ethnicity, and identity in politics across American, comparative, and international contexts.
notes: Only Politics majors may pursue this track.
Track requirements overlay the standard Politics major requirements.
Courses must be taken for a grade and factor into honors.
See the Race and Identity track webpage for current approved courses and guidelines.

junior_requirements: Two-semester junior independent work (JIW) sequence during junior year.
Fall: research prospectus developed in conjunction with POL 300; POL 300 practicum instructors serve as fall JIW advisers.
Spring: full-length junior paper (JP) that either builds on the prospectus or explores a new topic.
Goal: produce a well-reasoned, analytical essay using methods from political science.
junior_grading: Students receive a single POL 981 grade (weight 2.0) at the end of spring.
POL 981 is a weighted average: 30% fall JIW, 70% spring JP.
Students must earn at least a C in POL 981 to advance to senior year.
If POL 981 is below C, a new JP is required with a grade that brings the average of POL 981 and the new paper to at least C (using pre-late-penalty grades).
senior_requirements: Year-long senior thesis, typically ~100 double-spaced pages (rarely fewer than 80).
Thesis is usually written in the student's primary field and must be situated in existing scholarly literature.
All seniors must enroll in POL 498 (fall, P/D/F) and POL 499 (spring, letter grade).
To pass POL 498, students must meet with their adviser at least twice in the fall and submit a thesis progress report.
POL 499 records the final senior thesis grade.
POL 498 and POL 499 do NOT count as departmentals.
Thesis topics may build on the junior paper; limited text reuse is allowed with explicit self-citation (e.g., reusing literature review), in line with University attribution guidelines.

senior_departmental_exam.description: In lieu of a written comprehensive exam, seniors prepare and present a professional thesis poster describing their senior thesis research.
components: Design and preparation of a poster summarizing thesis question, methods, and results.
Formal presentation of the poster, with discussion and questions from faculty and peers.

majors.major_name: School of Public and International Affairs

requirement_blocks.title: Prerequisites
requirement_blocks.description: Students must complete four graded prerequisite courses (statistics, microeconomics, sociology/psychology, politics/history) with a grade of C or higher before the fall term of junior year.

course_groups.title: General Prerequisite Rules
requirements: Total of four prerequisite courses, completed before September of junior year.
All prerequisite courses must be taken on a graded (A-F) basis.
First-year seminars (FRS) may NOT count as prerequisites.
Students must earn a grade of C or higher in all courses counting toward prerequisites.
A Princeton course used as a prerequisite may also be used to satisfy a core requirement (if on the core list) or as a departmental elective (if on the electives list).

course_groups.title: Statistics Requirement (One Course)
options: ECO 202: Statistics and Data Analysis for Economics
POL 345: Introduction to Quantitative Social Science
constraints: AP credit may NOT be used to satisfy the statistics prerequisite.

course_groups.title: Microeconomics Requirement (One Course)
options: Advanced placement equivalency for ECO 100 (per University/AP guidelines)
notes: For AP/placement-based fulfillment, students must follow the ECO 100 advanced placement information on the undergraduate advising website.

course_groups.title: Sociology or Psychology Requirement (One Course)
requirements: One approved course in Sociology (SOC) or Psychology (PSY).
Students must consult the SPIA undergraduate program website for the current approved list of SOC/PSY courses that satisfy this prerequisite.

course_groups.title: Politics or History Requirement (One Course)
requirements: One approved course in Politics (POL) or History (HIS).
Students must consult the SPIA undergraduate program website for the current approved list of POL/HIS courses that satisfy this prerequisite.

course_groups.title: Transfer and Summer Course Policies for Prerequisites
requirements: A summer course or course taken abroad may count toward a prerequisite if:
- It has been approved by the relevant department; AND
- It has been approved by either the Office of International Programs or the student's residential college dean/assistant dean; AND
- It has been approved in advance by the SPIA undergraduate program office for use as a prerequisite.
All such approvals must be obtained in advance.

requirement_blocks.title: Core Course Requirements
requirement_blocks.description: SPIA majors must complete a set of core courses in public policy, research design, ethics, power & identity, and intermediate economics, plus a year-long senior thesis course sequence.

course_groups.title: SPIA Core Course Sequence
requirements: SPI 298: Introduction to Public Policy (fall only; normally taken sophomore year; must be completed no later than fall of junior year).
SPI 299: Research Design Seminar (fall only; juniors only; noncredit-bearing; supports junior paper design).
SPI 300: Research Seminar (spring only; juniors only; credit-bearing).
SPI 301: Policy Task Force (fall or spring; juniors only; prerequisite: SPI 298).
SPI 498: Senior Thesis I (fall only; seniors only).
SPI 499: Senior Thesis II (spring only; seniors only).
constraints: All core courses used to meet these requirements (except SPI 299, which is noncredit) must be taken at Princeton on a graded (A-F) basis.

course_groups.title: Power and Identity Requirement
requirements: One course that focuses on power and identity, from the SPIA-approved list.
Students must consult the SPIA undergraduate program website for the most current list of courses that fulfill this requirement.

course_groups.title: Ethics Requirement (One Course)
options: EGR 219: Professional Responsibility & Ethics: Succeeding Without Selling Your Soul

course_groups.title: Intermediate Economics Requirement (One Course)
options: ECO 310: Microeconomic Theory: A Mathematical Approach
notes: Students with little or no calculus experience are strongly advised to take MAT 103 as preparation for SPI 304.
Students who wish to take ECO 300, ECO 301, ECO 310 or ECO 311 are responsible for completing additional ECO/MAT prerequisites on their own.

requirement_blocks.title: Elective Courses (Six Courses)
requirement_blocks.description: SPIA majors must complete six elective courses, split between disciplinary breadth and intellectual depth, with additional constraints on department counts and regional focus.

course_groups.title: Overview and General Rules
requirements: Six elective courses total.
Electives must be chosen from SPIA-affiliated departments or SPIA-approved courses, per the official electives list.
All elective courses are recorded based on the home department code, not cross-listed departments.
Among the six electives, a student may take at most 3 electives from any single non-SPI department.
For the major as a whole, a student may not take more than 5 courses from a single department (excluding SPI courses).
Up to 3 elective courses may be taken through semester-long study abroad programs (subject to approval).

course_groups.title: Disciplinary Breadth Requirement (Three Courses)
requirements: Take 3 courses, each from a different SPIA-related department.
Eligible departments for breadth (by home listing): CEE, COS, EEB, GEO, HIS, MAE, POL, PSY, SOC, SPI.
ECO is excluded from the breadth requirement because economics is already required as a prerequisite/core.
Prerequisites and core courses may double-count toward disciplinary breadth, except ECO courses.

course_groups.title: Intellectual Depth Requirement (Three Courses)
course_groups.description: Students must choose ONE depth path: Disciplinary Depth OR Thematic Depth.
requirements: Disciplinary Depth: Take 3 courses in ONE SPIA-affiliated department:
- Eligible departments: CEE, COS, ECO, EEB, GEO, HIS, MAE, POL, PSY, SOC, SPI.
OR
Thematic Depth: Take 3 courses addressing a single theme, drawn from SPIA-affiliated departments or SPIA-approved courses.
themes: Community and Individual Health, Education & Well-being

course_groups.title: Regional Focus Requirement
requirements: Students must develop a regional focus in their coursework.
At least 2 courses must substantively focus on a particular geographic region.
The junior paper and/or senior thesis may count toward fulfilling the regional focus requirement if regionally focused.

requirement_blocks.title: Cross-Cultural or Policy-Relevant Field Experience
requirement_blocks.description: Beyond coursework, SPIA requires students to engage in an extracurricular cross-cultural or policy-relevant field experience.

course_groups.title: Experience Requirement
requirements: Students must complete one of the following types of experiences:
- Cross-cultural experience (which may include study abroad), OR
- Policy-relevant field experience (overseas or domestic).
Specific options, documentation requirements, and approval processes are detailed on the SPIA undergraduate program website.

junior_requirements: Junior independent work (junior paper, JP) is completed across two linked junior-year experiences:

1. SPI 299: Research Design Seminar (fall, noncredit-bearing) - focuses on formulating a researchable policy question, constructing concepts, evaluating hypotheses and policy solutions, and designing research.
2. SPI 300: Research Seminar (spring, credit-bearing) - a small, topical research seminar led by a faculty member where students conduct research and complete the JP.
The junior paper must address a policy-relevant question and use systematic, research-based analysis.
senior_requirements: All seniors must complete a year-long senior thesis on a significant public policy issue.
Students enroll in SPI 498: Senior Thesis I (fall) and SPI 499: Senior Thesis II (spring).
The thesis must clearly articulate a research question, use appropriate evidence and methods, and draw conclusions that contribute to policy debates.
A written progress structure (interim deadlines, drafts, and meetings) is defined by SPI 498/499 and the thesis adviser.

senior_departmental_exam.description: The SPIA senior comprehensive exam is an oral defense of the senior thesis.
components: Oral defense before faculty examiners, focused on the thesis and relevant policy domain.
Assessment of the student's expertise in their thesis topic and their ability to discuss implications and future directions.

requirement_blocks.title: Prerequisites
requirement_blocks.description: Three graded prerequisite courses are required before entering the Psychology major; pass/D/fail is not permitted.

course_groups.title: General Prerequisite Rules
requirements: Total of three prerequisite courses.
All prerequisites must be taken for a letter grade (no pass/D/fail).
Any alternative prerequisite set must be approved by the Director of Undergraduate Studies (DUS).

course_groups.title: Required Statistics Course (One Course)
options: A preapproved statistics course in another department (must be approved by the DUS).

course_groups.title: Additional Psychology/Neuroscience Courses (Two Courses)
notes: Courses must be completed on a graded basis.
Any substitutions or alternative combinations require DUS approval.

requirement_blocks.title: Departmental Course Requirements
requirement_blocks.description: Students must complete at least eight departmental courses in Psychology (in addition to the three prerequisite courses). Five must be at the 300 level or higher, and three must be at the 200 level or higher.

course_groups.title: Upper-Level Departmentals (Five Courses, 300+)
requirements: Total of five departmental courses at the 300 level or higher.
These can be PSY courses or courses cross-listed with PSY (as listed by the department).

subgroups.title: Required Methods Course
requirements: PSY 300: Research Methods (must be completed in junior year; typically offered once per academic year, usually in the fall).

subgroups.title: Additional Upper-Level Courses
requirements: Four additional PSY departmentals at the 300 or 400 level.
Specific 300- and 400-level offerings vary by year; students should consult current PSY course listings.

course_groups.title: Intermediate Departmentals (Three Courses, 200+)
course_groups.description: Three departmental courses at the 200 level or higher are required. Certain 200-level PSY/NEU courses are required if not already taken as prerequisites.
requirements: Total of three departmental courses at the 200 level or higher.
If any of the following were not taken as prerequisites, they must be taken as departmentals:
required_if_not_prereq: NEU 200 / PSY 200: Functional Neuroanatomy OR NEU 201 / PSY 258: Fundamentals of Neuroscience
notes: If a student already completed some or all of PSY 252, PSY 255, and NEU 200/PSY 200 or NEU 201/PSY 258 as prerequisites, the remaining 200-level-or-higher departmental requirements may be met with other 200-, 300-, or 400-level courses listed in or cross-listed with PSY.

requirement_blocks.title: Senior Thesis Course Sequence
requirement_blocks.description: All Psychology majors must complete a two-course senior thesis sequence in their final year.

course_groups.title: Required Senior Thesis Courses
requirements: PSY 498: Senior Thesis (Part I) - normally taken in the fall of senior year.
PSY 499: Senior Thesis (Part II) - normally taken in the spring of senior year.
notes: Students who are out of phase must still complete both courses; they may take PSY 498 in the spring and PSY 499 in the following fall as needed.
Enrollment in PSY 498/499 is required; specific registration timing is managed through term course selection.

junior_requirements: Students complete two junior papers (JPs), one in the fall and one in the spring of junior year, under the supervision of a faculty adviser.
The fall JP typically focuses on formulating a question and critically reviewing and synthesizing the relevant psychological literature.
The spring JP typically builds toward the thesis by developing an original idea, often in the form of a research proposal or similar extended project.
Each JP is written in close consultation with the adviser and is expected to demonstrate understanding of empirical research and clear written communication.
senior_requirements: All seniors complete an independent senior thesis in Psychology (experimental or theoretical), supervised by a faculty adviser.
The thesis normally includes a substantial review of relevant research literature and an original contribution (empirical or theoretical) to a psychological question.
Students enroll in PSY 498 (fall) and PSY 499 (spring) to support progress on the thesis across the full academic year.
The thesis is evaluated by the adviser and a second reader.

senior_departmental_exam.description: The senior departmental examination is a one-hour oral defense of the senior thesis.
components: A 10-15 minute presentation in which the student summarizes their thesis, including background, methods (if applicable), main arguments or findings, and conclusions.

Approximately 45 minutes of questions and discussion with two faculty examiners (typically the adviser and a second reader), covering the thesis, its theoretical and empirical background, and related topics in psychology.
An examination grade determined by the two faculty members based on the presentation and the student's responses.

requirement_blocks.title: Prerequisites
requirement_blocks.description: Any course offered by the Department of Religion may serve as a prerequisite for entering the major.

course_groups.title: General Prerequisite Rule
requirements: At least one REL course taken prior to declaring the major counts as the prerequisite.

requirement_blocks.title: Program of Study
requirement_blocks.description: Majors complete nine departmental courses plus Senior Thesis I (REL 498) and II (REL 499). Most juniors and seniors take two department courses per term.

course_groups.title: Junior Colloquium
requirements: REL 399: Junior Colloquium (taken in fall of junior year; counts toward the nine departmental courses)

course_groups.title: Senior Thesis Courses
requirements: REL 498: Senior Thesis I (fall of senior year)
REL 499: Senior Thesis II (spring of senior year)

course_groups.title: Stream Requirement
course_groups.description: Students select one of two streams (Traditions or Themes) in junior year, in consultation with the DUS. Students must complete at least three courses within their chosen stream.

subgroups.title: Traditions Stream
subgroups.description: Courses grouped by religious traditions, approaches, regions, or periods.

options.tradition: Ancient Judaism, Christianity, and Greek/Roman Religions

subgroups.title: Themes Stream
subgroups.description: A thematic focus crossing traditions, regions, or periods. Students select a theme in consultation with the DUS.
notes: Themes may be chosen from department suggestions or individually designed.
The DUS grants final approval for thematic plans.

course_groups.title: Additional Departmentals
requirements: Five additional REL courses beyond the stream requirement.
At least one must be designated 'Critical Approaches to the Study of Religion'.
Critical Approaches courses do NOT double-count for stream distributions.

requirement_blocks.title: Cognates
requirement_blocks.description: Up to two elective courses taught outside the Religion department may count as cognates if approved by the DUS.
rules: Cognates must meaningfully supplement the student's major coursework.
All other courses counting toward the major must be taught by Religion department faculty.
Cognates cannot double-count toward stream requirements.

tracks.summary: Students concentrate in a specific religious tradition or grouping. Requires at least three REL courses in one tradition group.
notes: Courses must align with the list published yearly on the department website.

tracks.summary: Students design a thematic focus that cuts across traditions, time periods, and geographies.
notes: Theme must be approved by the DUS; students may propose custom themes.

junior_requirements: REL 399 (Junior Colloquium) includes preparation of a 5-7 page junior paper proposal.
In the spring of junior year, students complete a 30-40 page junior paper under faculty supervision.
At the end of junior year, students meet with a faculty committee to discuss their work and senior thesis plans.
senior_requirements: Students complete a 70-90 page senior thesis under faculty supervision.
REL 498 (fall) includes meetings with advisers, annotated bibliography, thesis proposal, and draft material.
REL 499 (spring) supports continued thesis development and completion.

senior_departmental_exam.description: An oral examination at the end of senior year covering the thesis, the student's focus area, and broader departmental coursework.

requirement_blocks.title: Prerequisites
requirement_blocks.description: Students must demonstrate introductory-level proficiency in Russian prior to entering the major.

course_groups.title: Language Prerequisite
requirements: RUS 107 or placement equivalent
RUS 108 may also satisfy the prerequisite

requirement_blocks.title: Program of Study
requirement_blocks.description: Majors must complete eight departmental courses, a junior methods seminar, and the senior thesis sequence (SLA 498-499).

course_groups.title: Core Departmental Requirements
requirements: At least eight departmental courses total
Four upper-level courses must be taken within the department
At least two of the four upper-level courses must be core surveys (SLA 219, SLA 220, SLA 221)

course_groups.title: Cognate Departmentals
course_groups.description: Four courses may come from cognate areas depending on the student's interests.
notes: Examples include French or German literature for 19th-century prose interests.
Students interested in Russian/Soviet studies may take courses in history, politics, anthropology, or sociology via the Program in Russian and Eurasian Studies.

course_groups.title: Language Requirement
requirements: RUS 207
At least one advanced language course: RUS 208, 405, 406, 407, or 408
Alternatively, one upper-level literature-in-Russian course: SLA 308, 312, 350, or 413
notes: Students who place beyond RUS 207 or complete the RUS 103-108 heritage sequence work with the DUS to design an appropriate study plan.

requirement_blocks.title: Cognates
requirement_blocks.description: Students may count up to four cognate courses toward the major, depending on intellectual focus.
rules: Cognates must be approved by the director of undergraduate studies.
Cognates must meaningfully complement the student's major focus.

junior_requirements: Required junior methods seminar taken fall of junior year (credit-bearing).
Seminar includes work in Russian or another Slavic language and a research-methods session with the Slavic librarian.
Final assignment: annotated bibliography preparing for the fall JP.
Two junior papers (one per semester), each 20-25 pages, written in English but incorporating Slavic-language sources.
senior_requirements: Thesis written under departmental supervision through SLA 498-499.
Approx. 20,000-word thesis submitted two weeks before spring reading period.
Post-submission presentation: 5-minute presentation in Russian (or relevant Slavic language) followed by Q&A in English.

senior_departmental_exam.description: Take-home comprehensive exam covering Russian literature based on the core survey reading list. Students may substitute a limited number of works with DUS approval.

requirement_blocks.title: Prerequisites
requirement_blocks.description: Students are encouraged to complete at least one sociology course by the end of sophomore year. SOC 101 is highly recommended.

course_groups.title: Recommended Preparation
requirements: One course in sociology completed by end of sophomore year (SOC 101 recommended).

requirement_blocks.title: Program of Study
requirement_blocks.description: Majors must complete nine sociology courses plus the independent work requirements.

course_groups.title: Required Sociology Courses
requirements: SOC 101: Introduction to Sociology
SOC 300: Sociological Theory
SOC 301: Statistical Methods in Sociology
SOC 302: Research Methods in Sociology
notes: SOC 300 and SOC 301 are typically taken in the fall of junior year.
SOC 302 is normally taken in the spring.

course_groups.title: Departmentals Requirement
requirements: Nine total sociology courses (including SOC 101, 300, 301, 302).
notes: Up to two cognate courses may count toward the nine, with approval.
All courses counting toward the major must be taken for a letter grade.

requirement_blocks.title: Cognates
requirement_blocks.description: Up to two cognate courses from other departments may count toward the nine required departmentals.
rules: Cognates must have substantial sociological content.
Cognates must be approved by the Department of Sociology.
Cognates must be taken for a grade.

junior_requirements: One junior paper due near the end of spring semester.
Junior independent work begins in the fall.
SOC 300 and SOC 301 provide methodological preparation for the JP.
JP includes limited data analysis using primary or secondary data.
JP graded by adviser and a second reader.
senior_requirements: Senior thesis completed through SOC 498-499.
Thesis combines theoretical frameworks with extensive data analysis.
Students collecting their own data must obtain IRB approval.

senior_departmental_exam.description: Oral examination conducted in May, based on the senior thesis and its broader sociological subfield.

requirement_blocks.title: Prerequisites
requirement_blocks.description: Students must complete the Spanish and/or Portuguese language requirements through Princeton coursework or by placement test.

course_groups.title: Language Readiness
requirements: Completion of Spanish language sequence OR placement equivalent
Completion of Portuguese language sequence OR placement equivalent

requirement_blocks.title: General Program Requirements
requirement_blocks.description: Majors complete eight departmental courses (distribution varies by track).

course_groups.title: General Language Guidance
requirements: Spanish majors strongly advised to take one advanced language course (SPA 204-209 or SPA 307).
Portuguese majors must take at least one 200-level POR course.

course_groups.title: Study Abroad Rules
notes: Up to three courses per semester abroad may count for Track 1 or 2.
Up to two courses per semester abroad may count for Track 3 or 4.

tracks.track_name: Track 1: Spanish or Portuguese Language, Literature & Culture
tracks.description: Students specialize exclusively in Spanish OR Portuguese.

course_groups.title: Spanish Coursework
requirements: Eight SPA or cross-listed courses
One advanced Spanish language course (SPA 204-209)
One topics course above SPA 209
At least four courses at the 300+ level
One pre-1800 course
notes: Up to two cross-listed English-taught courses count if all written work is in Spanish.
Up to three courses abroad per semester may count.

course_groups.title: Portuguese Coursework
requirements: Eight POR or cross-listed courses
One intermediate language-level POR class (POR 107-109) may count
At least one course at the 200-level
At least one course at the 300-level or higher
notes: Up to two cross-listed English-taught courses count if written work is in Portuguese.
Princeton SPO summer programs count toward requirements.
Up to three courses abroad per semester may count.

tracks.track_name: Track 2: Spanish and Portuguese Languages, Literatures & Cultures
tracks.description: Students divide coursework between both languages.

course_groups.title: Spanish Requirements
requirements: Five SPA courses
One advanced Spanish language course (SPA 204-209)
One Spanish topics course above SPA 209
At least two SPA courses at the 300+ level

course_groups.title: Portuguese Requirements
requirements: Three POR courses

notes: Up to two English-taught cross-lists count if written work is in Spanish or Portuguese.
Up to three courses abroad per semester may count.

course_groups.title: Portuguese Requirements
requirements: Five POR courses
One intermediate language-level POR class (POR 107-109) may count
At least one 200-level POR course
At least one 300-level POR course

course_groups.title: Spanish Requirements
requirements: Three SPA courses

notes: Princeton SPO summer programs count.
Up to three courses abroad per semester may count.

tracks.track_name: Track 3: Interdisciplinary Track (Spanish or Portuguese + Related Field)
tracks.description: Combine Spanish or Portuguese with a secondary field.

course_groups.title: Spanish Requirements
requirements: Five SPA courses
One advanced Spanish language course (SPA 204-209)
One topics course above SPA 209
At least two SPA courses at the 300+ level

course_groups.title: Secondary Field Requirements
requirements: Three courses in a related field (approved by DUS)

notes: Up to two SPA courses abroad per semester may count.
Up to one secondary-field course abroad per semester may count.

course_groups.title: Portuguese Requirements
requirements: Five POR courses
One intermediate language-level POR course (POR 107-109) may count
At least one 200-level POR course
At least one 300-level POR course

course_groups.title: Secondary Field Requirements
requirements: Three courses in a related field (approved by DUS)

notes: Up to two POR courses abroad per semester may count.
Up to one secondary-field course abroad per semester may count.

tracks.track_name: Track 4: Creative Arts Track (Spanish or Portuguese + Creative Field)
tracks.description: Combine Spanish or Portuguese with creative arts (creative writing, theater, visual arts, translation).

course_groups.title: Spanish Requirements
requirements: Five SPA courses
One advanced language course (SPA 204-209)
One topics course above SPA 209
At least two SPA courses at the 300+ level

course_groups.title: Creative Arts Requirements
requirements: Three approved Creative Arts courses

notes: Up to two SPA courses abroad per semester may count.
Up to one Creative Arts course abroad per semester may count.

course_groups.title: Portuguese Requirements
requirements: Five POR courses
One intermediate language POR course (POR 107-109) may count
At least one 200-level POR course
At least one 300-level POR course

course_groups.title: Creative Arts Requirements
requirements: Three approved Creative Arts courses

notes: Up to two POR courses abroad per semester may count.
Up to one Creative Arts course abroad per semester may count.

rules: Cross-listed English-taught courses may count if all written work is completed in Spanish or Portuguese.
Cognate rules vary by track; secondary-field and creative-arts courses function as built-in cognates.

junior_requirements: Two junior papers (fall JP ~4000 words, spring JP ~5000-8000 words).
SPA/POR 330 strongly recommended as a junior research methods course.
JP may be written in English with a 3-page summary in target language, or fully in the target language.
senior_requirements: Year-long thesis through SPO 498-499.
Thesis typically 15,000-20,000 words.
Regular meetings with adviser and completion of staged drafts.

senior_departmental_exam.description: Oral presentation of the senior thesis followed by questions on the thesis, bibliography and departmental coursework.
